Private Geometric Median in Nearly-Linear Time

Syamantak Kumar University of Texas at Austin, syamantak@utexas.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Daogao Liu Google Research, liudaogao@gmail.com â€ƒâ€ƒ Kevin Tian University of Texas at Austin, kjtian@cs.utexas.edu â€ƒâ€ƒ Chutong Yang University of Texas at Austin, cyang98@utexas.edu
Abstract

Estimating the geometric median of a dataset is a robust counterpart to mean estimation, and is a fundamental problem in computational geometry. Recently, [HSU24] gave an (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-differentially private algorithm obtaining an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative approximation to the geometric median objective, 1nâˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ¥â‹…âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\|\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\|divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥, given a dataset ğ’Ÿ:={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚â„dassignğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Their algorithm requires nâ‰³dâ‹…1Î±â¢Ïµgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›â‹…ğ‘‘1ğ›¼italic-Ïµn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n â‰³ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± italic_Ïµ end_ARG samples, which they prove is information-theoretically optimal. This result is surprising because its error scales with the effective radius of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D (i.e., of a ball capturing most points), rather than the worst-case radius. We give an improved algorithm that obtains the same approximation quality, also using nâ‰³dâ‹…1Î±â¢Ïµgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›â‹…ğ‘‘1ğ›¼italic-Ïµn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n â‰³ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± italic_Ïµ end_ARG samples, but in time O~â¢(nâ¢d+dÎ±2)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¼2\widetilde{O}(nd+\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d + divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ). Our runtime is nearly-linear, plus the cost of the cheapest non-private first-order method due to [CLM+16]. To achieve our results, we use subsampling and geometric aggregation tools inspired by FriendlyCore [TCK+22] to speed up the â€œwarm startâ€ component of the [HSU24] algorithm, combined with a careful custom analysis of DP-SGDâ€™s sensitivity for the geometric median objective.

1 Introduction

The geometric median problem, also known as the Fermat-Weber problem, is one of the oldest problems in computational geometry. In this problem, we are given a dataset ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚â„dğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and our goal is to find a point ğ±â‹†âˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ±â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that minimizes the average Euclidean distance to points in the dataset:

ğ±â‹†âˆˆargâ¡minğ±âˆˆâ„dâ¡fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±),Â whereÂ â¢fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±):=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]â€–ğ±âˆ’ğ±iâ€–.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ±assignÂ whereÂ subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ±1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›normğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f_{\mathcal{D}}(% \mathbf{x}),\text{ where }f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n% ]}\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\|.bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) , where italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ . (1)

This problem has received widespread interest due to its applications in high-dimensional statistics. In particular, the geometric median of a dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D enjoys robustness properties that the mean (i.e., 1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ±i1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ±ğ‘–\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbf{x}_{i}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the minimizer of 1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥21ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–2\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert^{2}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) does not. For example, it is known (cf.Â LemmaÂ 4) that if greater than half of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D lies within a distance rğ‘Ÿritalic_r of some ğ±Â¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then the geometric median lies within Oâ¢(r)ğ‘‚ğ‘ŸO(r)italic_O ( italic_r ) of ğ±Â¯Â¯ğ±\bar{\mathbf{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG. Thus, the geometric median provides strong estimation guarantees even when ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D contains outliers. This is in contrast to simpler estimators such as the mean, which can be arbitrarily corrupted by a single outlier. As a result, studying the properties and computational aspects of the geometric median has a long history, see e.g., [Web29, LR91] for some famous examples.

In this paper, we provide improved algorithms for estimating (1) subject to (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-differential privacy (DP, DefinitionÂ 1), the de facto notion of provable privacy in modern machine learning. Privately computing the geometric median naturally fits into a recent line of work on designing DP algorithms in the presence of outliers. To explain the challenge of such problems, the definition of DP implies that the privacy-preserving guarantee must hold for worst-case datasets. This stringent definition affords DP a variety of desirable properties, most notably composition of private mechanisms (cf.Â [DR14], Section 3.5). However, it also begets challenges: for example, estimating the empirical mean of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D subject to (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP necessarily results in error scaling âˆRproportional-toabsentğ‘…\propto Râˆ italic_R, the diameter of the dataset (cf.Â Section 5, [BST14]). Moreover, the worst-case nature of DP is at odds with typical average-case machine learning settings, where most (or all) of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is drawn from a distribution that we wish to learn about. From an algorithm design standpoint, the question follows: how do we design methods that provide privacy guarantees for worst-case data, but also yield improved utility guarantees for (mostly) average-case data?

Such questions have been successfully addressed for various statistical tasks in recent work, including parameter estimation [BD14, KV17, BKSW19, DFM+20, BDKU20, BGS+21, AL22, LKJO22, KDH23, BHS23], clustering [NRS07, NSV16, CKM+21, TCK+22], and more. However, existing approaches for estimating (1) (even non-privately) are based on iterative optimization methods, as the geometric median does not admit a simple, closed-form solution. Much of the DP optimization toolkit is exactly plagued by the aforementioned â€œworst-case sensitivityâ€ issues, e.g., lower bounds for general stochastic optimization problems again scale with the domain size. This is troubling in the context of (1), because a major appeal of the geometric median is its robustness: its error should not be significantly affected by any small subset of the data. Privately estimating the geometric median thus poses an interesting technical challenge, beyond its potential appeal as a subroutine in downstream robust algorithms.

To explain the distinction between worst-case and average-case error rates in the context of (1), we introduce the following helpful notation: for all quantiles Ï„âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ01\tau\in[0,1]italic_Ï„ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], we let

r(Ï„):=argâ¡minrâ‰¥0â¡{âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±â‹†âˆ¥â‰¤râ‰¥Ï„â¢n},Â whereÂ â¢ğ±â‹†:=argâ¡minğ±âˆˆâ„dâ¡1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥,formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğœsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±â‹†ğ‘Ÿğœğ‘›assignÂ whereÂ subscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–r^{(\tau)}:=\arg\min_{r\geq 0}\left\{\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq r}\geq\tau n\right\},\text{ % where }\mathbf{x}_{\star}:=\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\frac{1}{n}% \sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert,italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Ï„ italic_n } , where bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ , (2)

when ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚â„dğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is clear from context. In other words, r(Ï„)superscriptğ‘Ÿğœr^{(\tau)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the smallest radius describing a ball around the geometric median ğ±â‹†subscriptğ±â‹†\mathbf{x}_{\star}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT containing at least Ï„â¢nğœğ‘›\tau nitalic_Ï„ italic_n points in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. We also use Rğ‘…Ritalic_R to denote an a priori overall domain size bound, where we are guaranteed that ğ’ŸâŠ‚ğ”¹dâ¢(R)ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D âŠ‚ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ). Note that in general, it is possible for, e.g., r(0.9)â‰ªRmuch-less-thansuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9ğ‘…r^{(0.9)}\ll Ritalic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ª italic_R if â‰ˆ10%absentpercent10\approx 10\%â‰ˆ 10 % of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D consists of outliers with atypical norms. Due to the robust nature of the geometric median (i.e., the aforementioned LemmaÂ 4), a natural target is estimation error scaling with the â€œeffective radiusâ€ r(Ï„)superscriptğ‘Ÿğœr^{(\tau)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some quantile Ï„âˆˆ(0.5,1)ğœ0.51\tau\in(0.5,1)italic_Ï„ âˆˆ ( 0.5 , 1 ). This is a much stronger guarantee than the error rates âˆRproportional-toabsentğ‘…\propto Râˆ italic_R that typical DP optimization methods give.

Because a simple argument (LemmaÂ 3) shows that r(Ï„)=Oâ¢(fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†))superscriptğ‘Ÿğœğ‘‚subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†r^{(\tau)}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) for all Ï„<1ğœ1\tau<1italic_Ï„ < 1, in this introduction our goal will be to approximate the minimizer of (1) to additive error Î±â¢fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†\alpha f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})italic_Î± italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1)italic_Î± âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), i.e., to give Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative error guarantees on optimizing fğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿf_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.111Our results, as well as those of [HSU24], in fact give stronger additive error bounds of Î±â¢r(Ï„)ğ›¼superscriptğ‘Ÿğœ\alpha r^{(\tau)}italic_Î± italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any fixed Ï„âˆˆ(0.5,1)ğœ0.51\tau\in(0.5,1)italic_Ï„ âˆˆ ( 0.5 , 1 ). Again, datasets with outliers may have fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)â‰ªRmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†ğ‘…f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})\ll Ritalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ª italic_R, so this goal is beyond the reach of naÃ¯vely applying DP optimization methods.

In a recent exciting work, [HSU24] bypassed this obstacle and obtained such private multiplicative approximations to the geometric median, and with near-optimal sample complexity. Assuming that ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D has size nâ‰³dâ‹…1Î±â¢Ïµgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›â‹…ğ‘‘1ğ›¼italic-Ïµn\gtrsim\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n â‰³ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± italic_Ïµ end_ARG,222In this introduction only, we use O~,â‰²,â‰³~ğ‘‚less-than-or-similar-togreater-than-or-equivalent-to\widetilde{O},\lesssim,\gtrsimover~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG , â‰² , â‰³ to hide polylogarithmic factors in problem parameters, i.e., dğ‘‘ditalic_d, 1Î±1ğ›¼\frac{1}{\alpha}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG, 1Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{\epsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG, 1Î´1ğ›¿\frac{1}{\delta}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG, and Rrğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, where ğ’ŸâŠ†ğ”¹dâ¢(R)ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}\subseteq\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D âŠ† roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) and râ‰¤r(0.9)ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9r\leq r^{(0.9)}italic_r â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Our formal theorem statements explicitly state our dependences on all parameters. [HSU24] gave two algorithms for estimating (1) to Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative error (cf.Â AppendixÂ A). They also proved a matching lower bound, showing that this many samples is information-theoretically necessary.333Intuitively, we require Î±â‰ˆdâˆ’1/2ğ›¼superscriptğ‘‘12\alpha\approx d^{-1/2}italic_Î± â‰ˆ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to obtain nontrivial mean estimation when ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D consists of i.i.d.Â Gaussian data (as a typical radius is â‰ˆdabsentğ‘‘\approx\sqrt{d}â‰ˆ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG), matching known sample complexity lower bounds of â‰ˆdÏµabsentğ‘‘italic-Ïµ\approx\frac{d}{\epsilon}â‰ˆ divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG for Gaussian mean estimation [KLSU19]. From both a theoretical and practical perspective, the main outstanding question left by [HSU24] is that of computational efficiency: in particular, the [HSU24] algorithms ran in time O~â¢(n2â¢d+n3â¢Ïµ2)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘›3superscriptitalic-Ïµ2\widetilde{O}(n^{2}d+n^{3}\epsilon^{2})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) or O~â¢(n2â¢d+nâ¢d2+d4.372)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘2superscriptğ‘‘4.372\widetilde{O}(n^{2}d+nd^{2}+d^{4.372})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d + italic_n italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4.372 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). This leaves a significant gap between algorithms for privately solving (1), and their counterparts in the non-private setting, where [CLM+16] showed that (1) could be approximated to Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative error in nearly-linear time O~â¢(minâ¡(nâ¢d,dÎ±2))~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¼2\widetilde{O}(\min(nd,\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}}))over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( roman_min ( italic_n italic_d , divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) ).

1.1 Our results

Our main contribution is a faster algorithm for privately approximating (1) to Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative error.

Theorem 1 (informal, see TheoremÂ 4).

Let ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚ğ”¹dâ¢(R)ğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0ğ‘…0R>0italic_R > 0, 0<râ‰¤r(0.9)0ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.90<r\leq r^{(0.9)}0 < italic_r â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (Î±,Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]3ğ›¼italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript013(\alpha,\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{3}( italic_Î± , italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. There is an (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP algorithm that returns ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG such that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´, fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±^)â‰¤(1+Î±)â¢fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿ^ğ±1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}})\leq(1+\alpha)f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{% \star})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) â‰¤ ( 1 + italic_Î± ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), assuming nâ‰³dÎ±â¢Ïµgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ›¼italic-Ïµn\gtrsim\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\alpha\epsilon}italic_n â‰³ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± italic_Ïµ end_ARG. The algorithm runs in time O~â¢(nâ¢d+dÎ±2)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¼2\widetilde{O}(nd+\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d + divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ).

To briefly explain TheoremÂ 1â€™s statement, it uses a priori knowledge of 0<r<R0ğ‘Ÿğ‘…0<r<R0 < italic_r < italic_R such that Rğ‘…Ritalic_R upper bounds the domain size of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and rğ‘Ÿritalic_r lower bounds the â€œeffective radiusâ€ r(0.9)superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9r^{(0.9)}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. However, its runtime only depends polylogarithmically on the aspect ratio Rrğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, rather than polynomially (as naÃ¯ve DP optimization methods would); we also remark that our sample complexity is independent of Rrğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG.

The runtime of TheoremÂ 1 is nearly-linear in the regime nâ‰³1Î±2greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›1superscriptğ›¼2n\gtrsim\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}italic_n â‰³ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG (e.g., if dâ‹…1Ïµâ‰³1Î±greater-than-or-equivalent-toâ‹…ğ‘‘1italic-Ïµ1ğ›¼\sqrt{d}\cdot\frac{1}{\epsilon}\gtrsim\frac{1}{\alpha}square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG â‰³ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG), but more generally it does incur an additive overhead of dÎ±2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¼2\frac{d}{\alpha^{2}}divide start_ARG italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. This overhead matches the fastest non-private first-order method for approximating (1) to Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative error, due to [CLM+16]. We note that [CLM+16] also gave a custom second-order interior-point method, that non-privately solves (1) in time O~â¢(nâ¢d)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ), i.e., with polylogarithmic dependence on 1Î±1ğ›¼\frac{1}{\alpha}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± end_ARG. We leave removing this additive runtime term in the DP setting, or proving this is impossible in concrete query models, as a challenging question for future work.

Our algorithm follows a roadmap given by [HSU24], who split their algorithm into two phases: an initial â€œwarm startâ€ phase that computes an Oâ¢(1)ğ‘‚1O(1)italic_O ( 1 )-multiplicative approximation of the geometric median, and a secondary â€œboostingâ€ phase that uses iterative optimization methods to improve the warm start to an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative approximation. The role of the warm start is to improve the domain size of the boosting phase to scale with the effective radius. However, both the warm start and the boosting phases of [HSU24] required superlinear â‰ˆn2â¢dabsentsuperscriptğ‘›2ğ‘‘\approx n^{2}dâ‰ˆ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d time. Our improvement to the warm start phase of the [HSU24] is quite simple, and may be of independent interest, so we provide a self-contained statement here.

Theorem 2 (informal, see TheoremÂ 3).

Let ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚ğ”¹dâ¢(R)ğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0ğ‘…0R>0italic_R > 0, 0<râ‰¤r(0.9)0ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.90<r\leq r^{(0.9)}0 < italic_r â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. There is an (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP algorithm that returns ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG such that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´, fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±^)=Oâ¢(fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†))subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿ^ğ±ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}})=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ), assuming nâ‰³dÏµgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›ğ‘‘italic-Ïµn\gtrsim\frac{\sqrt{d}}{\epsilon}italic_n â‰³ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG. The algorithm runs in time O~â¢(nâ¢d)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ).

1.2 Our techniques

As discussed previously, our algorithm employs a similar framework as [HSU24]. It is convenient to further split the warm start phase of the algorithm into two parts: finding an estimate r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG of the effective radius of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and finding an approximate centerpoint at distance Oâ¢(r^)ğ‘‚^ğ‘ŸO(\hat{r})italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) from the geometric median ğ±â‹†subscriptğ±â‹†\mathbf{x}_{\star}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Radius estimation.

Our radius estimation algorithm is almost identical to that in [HSU24], Section 2.1, which uses the sparse vector technique (cf.Â LemmaÂ 2) to detect the first time an estimate r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is such that most points have â‰¥34absent34\geq\frac{3}{4}â‰¥ divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D at a distance of â‰ˆr^absent^ğ‘Ÿ\approx\hat{r}â‰ˆ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. The estimate r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is geometrically updated over a grid of size Oâ¢(logâ¡(Rr))ğ‘‚ğ‘…ğ‘ŸO(\log(\frac{R}{r}))italic_O ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) ). NaÃ¯vely implemented, this strategy takes â‰³n2â¢dgreater-than-or-equivalent-toabsentsuperscriptğ‘›2ğ‘‘\gtrsim n^{2}dâ‰³ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d time due to the need for pairwise distance comparisons (cf.Â AppendixÂ A); even if dimesionality reduction techniques are used, this step appears to require Î©â¢(n2)Î©superscriptğ‘›2\Omega(n^{2})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time. We make a simple observation that a random sample of â‰ˆlogâ¡(1Î´)absent1ğ›¿\approx\log(\frac{1}{\delta})â‰ˆ roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) points from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D is enough to determine whether a given point has â‰«Î²much-greater-thanabsentğ›½\gg\betaâ‰« italic_Î² neighbors, or â‰ªÎ³much-less-thanabsentğ›¾\ll\gammaâ‰ª italic_Î³, for appropriate (constant) quantile thresholds Î²,Î³ğ›½ğ›¾\beta,\gammaitalic_Î² , italic_Î³, which is enough to obtain an O~â¢(nâ¢d)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ) runtime.

Centerpoint estimation.

Our centerpoint estimation step departs from [HSU24], Section 2.2, who analyzed a custom variant of DP gradient descent with geometrically-decaying step sizes. We make the simple observation that directly applying the FriendlyCore algorithm of [HSU24] yields the same result. However, the standard implementation of FriendlyCore again requires Î©â¢(n2)Î©superscriptğ‘›2\Omega(n^{2})roman_Î© ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time to estimate weights for each data point. We again show that FriendlyCore can be sped up to run in O~â¢(nâ¢d)~ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘\widetilde{O}(nd)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_n italic_d ) time (independently of Rrğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG) via weights estimated through subsampling. Our privacy proof of this subsampled variant is subtle, and based on an argument (LemmaÂ 1) that couples our algorithm to an idealized algorithm that never fails to be private. We use this to account for the privacy loss due to the failure of our subsampling, i.e., if the estimates are inaccurate. We note that the [HSU24] algorithm for this step already ran in nearly-linear â‰ˆnâ¢dâ¢logâ¡(Rr)absentğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\approx nd\log(\frac{R}{r})â‰ˆ italic_n italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) time, so we obtain an asymptotic improvement only if Rrğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ\frac{R}{r}divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is large.

Boosting.

The most technically novel part of our algorithm is in the boosting phase, which takes as input a radius and centerpoint estimate from the previous steps, and outputs an Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-multiplicative approximation to (1). Like [HSU24], we use iterative optimization methods to implement this phase. However, a major bottleneck to a faster algorithm is the lack of a nearly-linear time DP solver for non-smooth empirical risk minimization (ERM) problems. Indeed, such O~â¢(1)~ğ‘‚1\widetilde{O}(1)over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( 1 )-pass optimizers are known only when the objective is convex and sufficiently smooth [FKT20], or nâ‰³d2greater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›superscriptğ‘‘2n\gtrsim d^{2}italic_n â‰³ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples are taken [CJJ+23]. This is an issue, because while computing the geometric median (1) is a convex ERM problem, it is non-smooth, and nontrivial multiplicative guarantees are possible even with nâ‰ˆdğ‘›ğ‘‘n\approx\sqrt{d}italic_n â‰ˆ square-root start_ARG italic_d end_ARG samples.

We give a custom analysis of DP-SGD, specifically catered to the (non-smooth) ERM objective (1). Our main contribution is a tighter sensitivity analysis of DP-SGDâ€™s iterates, leveraging the structure of the geometric median. To motivate this observation, consider coupled algorithms with iterates ğ³ğ³\mathbf{z}bold_z, ğ³â€²superscriptğ³â€²\mathbf{z}^{\prime}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, both taking gradient steps with respect to the subsampled function âˆ¥â‹…âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVertâˆ¥ â‹… - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ for some dataset element ğ±iâˆˆğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ’Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D. A simple calculation (12) shows these gradients are unit vectors ğ®ğ®\mathbf{u}bold_u, ğ®â€²superscriptğ®â€²\mathbf{u}^{\prime}bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, in the directions of ğ³âˆ’ğ±iğ³subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ³â€²âˆ’ğ±isuperscriptğ³â€²subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{z}^{\prime}-\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively. It is not hard to formalize (LemmaÂ 11) that updating ğ³â†ğ³âˆ’Î·â¢ğ®â†ğ³ğ³ğœ‚ğ®\mathbf{z}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}-\eta\mathbf{u}bold_z â† bold_z - italic_Î· bold_u and ğ³â€²â†ğ³â€²âˆ’Î·â¢ğ®â€²â†superscriptğ³â€²superscriptğ³â€²ğœ‚superscriptğ®â€²\mathbf{z}^{\prime}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}^{\prime}-\eta\mathbf{u}^{\prime}bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â† bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_Î· bold_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is always contractive, unless ğ³,ğ³â€²ğ³superscriptğ³â€²\mathbf{z},\mathbf{z}^{\prime}bold_z , bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT were both already very close to ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (and hence, each other) to begin with. We use this structural result to inductively control DP-SGDâ€™s sensitivity, which lets us leverage a prior reduction from private optimization to stable optimization [FKT20].

Our result is the first we are aware of that obtains a nearly-linear runtime for DP-SGD on a structured non-smooth problem. We were inspired by [ALT24], who also gave faster runtimes for (smooth) DP optimization problems with outliers under further assumptions on the objective. We hope that our work motivates future DP optimization methods that harness problem structure for improved rates.

1.3 Related work

Differentially private convex optimization.

Differentially private convex optimization has been studied extensively for over a decade [CM08, KST12, BST14, KJ16, BFGT20, FKT20, BGN21, GLL22, GLL+23] and inspired the influential DP-SGD algorithm widely adopted in deep learning [ACG+16]. In the classic setting, where functions are assumed to be Lipschitz and defined over a convex domain of diameter Rğ‘…Ritalic_R, optimal rates have been achieved with linear dependence on Rğ‘…Ritalic_R [BFTGT19]. Recent years have seen significant advancements in optimizing the gradient complexity of DP stochastic convex optimization [FKT20, AFKT21, KLL21, ZTC22, CJJ+23, CCGT24]. Despite these efforts, a nearly-linear gradient complexity has only been established for sufficiently smooth functions [FKT20, ZTC22, CCGT24] and for non-smooth functions [CJJ+23] when the condition nâ‰³dgreater-than-or-equivalent-toğ‘›ğ‘‘\sqrt{n}\gtrsim dsquare-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG â‰³ italic_d is satisfied.

Differential privacy with average-case data.

Adapting noise to the inherent properties of data, rather than catering to worst-case scenarios, is critical for making differential privacy practical in real-world applications. Several important approaches have emerged in this direction: smooth sensitivity frameworks [NRS07] that refine local sensitivity to make it private; instance optimality techniques [AD20] that provide tailored guarantees for specific datasets; methods with improved performance under distributional assumptions such as sub-Gaussian or heavy-tailed i.i.d.Â data [CWZ21, AL23, ALT24]; and data-dependent sensitivity computations that adapt during algorithm execution [ATMR21]. These approaches collectively represent the frontier in balancing privacy and utility beyond worst-case analyses. We view our work as another contribution towards this broader program.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we collect preliminary results used throughout the paper. We define our notation in SectionÂ 2.1. We then formally state helper definitions and known tools from the literature on differential privacy and computing the geometric median in SectionsÂ 2.2 andÂ 2.3 respectively.

2.1 Notation and probability basics

Throughout, vectors are denoted in lowercase boldface, and the all-zeroes and all-ones vectors in dimension dğ‘‘ditalic_d are respectively denoted ğŸdsubscript0ğ‘‘\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğŸdsubscript1ğ‘‘\mathbf{1}_{d}bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We use âˆ¥â‹…âˆ¥delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥â‹…\left\lVert\cdot\right\rVertâˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ to denote the Euclidean (â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) norm of a vector argument. We use [d]delimited-[]ğ‘‘[d][ italic_d ] to denote {iâˆˆâ„•âˆ£1â‰¤iâ‰¤d}conditional-setğ‘–â„•1ğ‘–ğ‘‘\{i\in\mathbb{N}\mid 1\leq i\leq d\}{ italic_i âˆˆ roman_â„• âˆ£ 1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_d }. We use ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ,r):={ğ±âˆˆâ„dâˆ£âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğâˆ¥â‰¤r}assignsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğğ‘Ÿconditional-setğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}^{d}(\boldsymbol{\mu},r):=\{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\mid\left% \lVert\mathbf{x}-\boldsymbol{\mu}\right\rVert\leq r\}roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_italic_Î¼ , italic_r ) := { bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r } to denote the Euclidean ball of radius r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0italic_r > 0 around ğâˆˆâ„dğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{\mu}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_Î¼ âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; when ğğ\boldsymbol{\mu}bold_italic_Î¼ is unspecified, then ğ=ğŸdğsubscript0ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{\mu}=\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_italic_Î¼ = bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by default. For a compact set ğ’¦âŠ†â„dğ’¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{K}\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_K âŠ† roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we use ğš·ğ’¦â¢(ğ±)subscriptğš·ğ’¦ğ±\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{x})bold_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) to denote the Euclidean projection argâ¡minğ²âˆˆğ’¦â¡âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥subscriptğ²ğ’¦ğ±ğ²\arg\min_{\mathbf{y}\in\mathcal{K}}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVertroman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_y âˆˆ caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥.

We let ğ•€â„°subscriptğ•€â„°\mathbb{I}_{\mathcal{E}}roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the 00-1111 indicator random variable corresponding to an event â„°â„°\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E. For two densities Î¼,Î½ğœ‡ğœˆ\mu,\nuitalic_Î¼ , italic_Î½ on the same probability space Î©Î©\Omegaroman_Î© and Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1italic_Î± > 1, we define the Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±-RÃ©nyi divergence by:

DÎ±â¢(Î¼âˆ¥Î½):=1Î±âˆ’1â¢logâ¡(âˆ«(Î¼â¢(Ï‰)Î½â¢(Ï‰))Î±â¢Î½â¢(Ï‰)â¢dâ¢Ï‰).assignsubscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğœ‡ğœˆ1ğ›¼1superscriptğœ‡ğœ”ğœˆğœ”ğ›¼ğœˆğœ”dğœ”D_{\alpha}(\mu\|\nu):=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(\int\left(\frac{\mu(\omega)}% {\nu(\omega)}\right)^{\alpha}\nu(\omega)\textup{d}\omega\right).italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Î¼ âˆ¥ italic_Î½ ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± - 1 end_ARG roman_log ( âˆ« ( divide start_ARG italic_Î¼ ( italic_Ï‰ ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î½ ( italic_Ï‰ ) end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î½ ( italic_Ï‰ ) d italic_Ï‰ ) .

We use ğ’©â¢(ğ,Ïƒ2â¢ğˆd)ğ’©ğsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğˆğ‘‘\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{\mu},\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d})caligraphic_N ( bold_italic_Î¼ , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) to denote the multivariate normal distribution with mean ğâˆˆâ„dğsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\boldsymbol{\mu}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_italic_Î¼ âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and covariance Ïƒ2â¢ğˆdsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğˆğ‘‘\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{d}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ğˆdsubscriptğˆğ‘‘\mathbf{I}_{d}bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the dÃ—dğ‘‘ğ‘‘d\times ditalic_d Ã— italic_d identity matrix. We let ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î»)ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾ğœ†\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)sansserif_Laplace ( italic_Î» ) be the Laplace distribution with scale parameter Î»â‰¥0ğœ†0\lambda\geq 0italic_Î» â‰¥ 0, whose density is âˆexpâ¡(âˆ’|â‹…|Î»)\propto\exp(-\frac{|\cdot|}{\lambda})âˆ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG | â‹… | end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î» end_ARG ). We let ğ–´ğ—‡ğ—‚ğ–¿â¢(S)ğ–´ğ—‡ğ—‚ğ–¿ğ‘†\mathsf{Unif}(S)sansserif_Unif ( italic_S ) denote the uniform distribution over a set Sğ‘†Sitalic_S, and ğ–¡ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—‡â¢(p)ğ–¡ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—‡ğ‘\mathsf{Bern}(p)sansserif_Bern ( italic_p ) denote the Bernoulli distribution taking on values {0,1}01\{0,1\}{ 0 , 1 } with mean pâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘01p\in[0,1]italic_p âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]. We refer to a product distribution consisting of kğ‘˜kitalic_k i.i.d.Â copies of a base distribution ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by ğ’ŸâŠ—ksuperscriptğ’Ÿtensor-productabsentğ‘˜\mathcal{D}^{\otimes k}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We also use the bounded Laplace distribution with parameters Î»,Ï„â‰¥0ğœ†ğœ0\lambda,\tau\geq 0italic_Î» , italic_Ï„ â‰¥ 0, denoted ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î»,Ï„)ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾ğœ†ğœ\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\lambda,\tau)sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( italic_Î» , italic_Ï„ ), which is the distribution of Xâˆ¼ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î»)similar-toğ‘‹ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾ğœ†X\sim\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)italic_X âˆ¼ sansserif_Laplace ( italic_Î» ) conditioned on |X|â‰¤Ï„ğ‘‹ğœ|X|\leq\tau| italic_X | â‰¤ italic_Ï„.

Finally, we require the following standard bound on binomial concentration.

Fact 1 (Chernoff bound).

For all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ], let Xiâˆ¼ğ–¡ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—‡â¢(pi)similar-tosubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ–¡ğ–¾ğ—‹ğ—‡subscriptğ‘ğ‘–X_{i}\sim\mathsf{Bern}(p_{i})italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¼ sansserif_Bern ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for some piâˆˆ[0,1]subscriptğ‘ğ‘–01p_{i}\in[0,1]italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ], and let Î¼:=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]piassignğœ‡subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘–\mu:=\sum_{i\in[n]}p_{i}italic_Î¼ := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Î¼^:=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]Xiassign^ğœ‡subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–\hat{\mu}:=\sum_{i\in[n]}X_{i}over^ start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then,

Prâ¡[Î¼^>(1+Ïµ)â¢Î¼]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµ2â¢Î¼2+Ïµ)â¢Â for allÂ â¢Ïµâ‰¥0,Pr^ğœ‡1italic-Ïµğœ‡superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğœ‡2italic-ÏµÂ for allÂ italic-Ïµ0\displaystyle\Pr\left[\hat{\mu}>(1+\epsilon)\mu\right]\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\text{ for all }\epsilon\geq 0,roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG > ( 1 + italic_Ïµ ) italic_Î¼ ] â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) for all italic_Ïµ â‰¥ 0 ,
Prâ¡[Î¼^<(1âˆ’Ïµ)â¢Î¼]â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµ2â¢Î¼2)â¢Â for allÂ â¢Ïµâˆˆ(0,1).Pr^ğœ‡1italic-Ïµğœ‡superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğœ‡2Â for allÂ italic-Ïµ01\displaystyle\Pr\left[\hat{\mu}<(1-\epsilon)\mu\right]\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{2}\right)\text{ for all }\epsilon\in(0,1).roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_Î¼ end_ARG < ( 1 - italic_Ïµ ) italic_Î¼ ] â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) for all italic_Ïµ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ) .

2.2 Differential privacy

Let ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X be some domain, and let ğ’Ÿâˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a dataset consisting of nğ‘›nitalic_n elements from ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. We say that two datasets ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³nsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are neighboring if their symmetric difference has size 1111, i.e., they differ in a single element. We use the following definition of differential privacy in this paper.

Definition 1 (Differential privacy).

Let (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.444In principle, the privacy parameter Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ can be larger than 1111. However, in this paper, sample complexities are unaffected up to constants for any Ïµâ‰¥1italic-Ïµ1\epsilon\geq 1italic_Ïµ â‰¥ 1 if we simply obtain (1,Î´)1ğ›¿(1,\delta)( 1 , italic_Î´ )-DP guarantees rather than (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP guarantees, which are only stronger. Thus we state all results for Ïµâˆˆ[0,1]italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in[0,1]italic_Ïµ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] for convenience, which simplifies some bounds. We say that a randomized algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’³nâ†’Î©:ğ’œâ†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›Î©\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© satisfies (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-differential privacy (or, is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP) if for all events â„°âŠ†Î©â„°Î©\mathcal{E}\subseteq\Omegacaligraphic_E âŠ† roman_Î©, and for all neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

Prâ¡[ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆˆâ„°]â‰¤expâ¡(Ïµ)â¢Prâ¡[ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿâ€²)âˆˆâ„°]+Î´.Prğ’œğ’Ÿâ„°italic-ÏµPrğ’œsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²â„°ğ›¿\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]\leq\exp(\epsilon)\Pr% \left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta.roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] â‰¤ roman_exp ( italic_Ïµ ) roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] + italic_Î´ .

DP algorithms satisfy basic composition (Theorem B.1, [DR14]), i.e., if ğ’œ1:ğ’³nâ†’Î©1:subscriptğ’œ1â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›subscriptÎ©1\mathcal{A}_{1}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omega_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Ïµ1,Î´1)subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptğ›¿1(\epsilon_{1},\delta_{1})( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP and ğ’œ2:ğ’³nÃ—Î©1â†’Î©2:subscriptğ’œ2â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›subscriptÎ©1subscriptÎ©2\mathcal{A}_{2}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\times\Omega_{1}\to\Omega_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Ïµ2,Î´2)subscriptitalic-Ïµ2subscriptğ›¿2(\epsilon_{2},\delta_{2})( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP, then running ğ’œ2subscriptğ’œ2\mathcal{A}_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D and the output of ğ’œ1â¢(ğ’Ÿ)subscriptğ’œ1ğ’Ÿ\mathcal{A}_{1}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) is (Ïµ1+Ïµ2,Î´1+Î´2)subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ2subscriptğ›¿1subscriptğ›¿2(\epsilon_{1}+\epsilon_{2},\delta_{1}+\delta_{2})( italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-DP. We next state the Gaussian mechanism. Recall that if ğ¯:ğ’³nâ†’â„k:ğ¯â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a vector-valued function of a dataset, we say ğ¯ğ¯\mathbf{v}bold_v has sensitivity Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î” if for all neighboring ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have âˆ¥ğ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆ’ğ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿâ€²)âˆ¥â‰¤Î”delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ¯ğ’Ÿğ¯superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²Î”\left\lVert\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D})-\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime})\right% \rVert\leq\Deltaâˆ¥ bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) - bold_v ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ roman_Î”.

Fact 2 (Theorem A.1, [DR14]).

Let ğ¯:ğ’³nâ†’â„k:ğ¯â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have sensitivity Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, and let (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, drawing a sample from ğ’©â¢(ğ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿ),Ïƒ2â¢ğˆk)ğ’©ğ¯ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğˆğ‘˜\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}),\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP, for any Ïƒâ‰¥2â¢Î”Ïµâ‹…logâ¡(2Î´)ğœâ‹…2Î”italic-Ïµ2ğ›¿\sigma\geq\frac{2\Delta}{\epsilon}\cdot\sqrt{\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}italic_Ïƒ â‰¥ divide start_ARG 2 roman_Î” end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG â‹… square-root start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG.

We also require the bounded Laplace mechanism, which is known to give the following guarantee.

Fact 3 (Lemma 9, [ALT24]).

Let s:ğ’³nâ†’â„:ğ‘ â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›â„s:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}italic_s : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„ have sensitivity Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”, and let (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, drawing Î¾âˆ¼ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î”Ïµ,Ï„)similar-toğœ‰ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾Î”italic-Ïµğœ\xi\sim\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\frac{\Delta}{\epsilon},\tau)italic_Î¾ âˆ¼ sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( divide start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG , italic_Ï„ ) and outputting sâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)+Î¾ğ‘ ğ’Ÿğœ‰s(\mathcal{D})+\xiitalic_s ( caligraphic_D ) + italic_Î¾ is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP for any Ï„â‰¥Î”Ïµâ¢logâ¡(4Î´)ğœÎ”italic-Ïµ4ğ›¿\tau\geq\frac{\Delta}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4}{\delta})italic_Ï„ â‰¥ divide start_ARG roman_Î” end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ).

FactÂ 3 is proven in [ALT24] using a coupling argument, using the fact that ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î»)ğ–¡ğ—ˆğ—ğ—‡ğ–½ğ–¾ğ–½ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾ğœ†\mathsf{BoundedLaplace}(\lambda)sansserif_BoundedLaplace ( italic_Î» ) and ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾â¢(Î»)ğ–«ğ–ºğ—‰ğ—…ğ–ºğ–¼ğ–¾ğœ†\mathsf{Laplace}(\lambda)sansserif_Laplace ( italic_Î» ) result in the same sample except with some probability. We appeal to this privacy proof technique several times in SectionÂ 3, so we state it explicitly here for convenience.

Lemma 1.

For (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ’œ:ğ’³nâ†’Î©:ğ’œâ†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›Î©\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© be an (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP algorithm, and let ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG be an algorithm such that on any input ğ’Ÿâˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have that the total variation distance between ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)ğ’œğ’Ÿ\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) and ğ’œÂ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿ)Â¯ğ’œğ’Ÿ\overline{\mathcal{A}}(\mathcal{D})overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D ) is at most Î´â€²superscriptğ›¿â€²\delta^{\prime}italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is an (Ïµ,Î´+4â¢Î´â€²)italic-Ïµğ›¿4superscriptğ›¿â€²(\epsilon,\delta+4\delta^{\prime})( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ + 4 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )-DP algorithm.

Proof.

For neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and any event â„°âˆˆÎ©â„°Î©\mathcal{E}\in\Omegacaligraphic_E âˆˆ roman_Î©, we have that

Prâ¡[ğ’œÂ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆˆâ„°]PrÂ¯ğ’œğ’Ÿâ„°\displaystyle\Pr\left[\overline{\mathcal{A}}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]roman_Pr [ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] â‰¤Prâ¡[ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆˆâ„°]+Î´â€²absentPrğ’œğ’Ÿâ„°superscriptğ›¿â€²\displaystyle\leq\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta% ^{\prime}â‰¤ roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¤expâ¡(Ïµ)â¢Prâ¡[ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿâ€²)âˆˆâ„°]+Î´+Î´â€²absentitalic-ÏµPrğ’œsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²â„°ğ›¿superscriptğ›¿â€²\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\epsilon\right)\Pr\left[\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{% \prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta+\delta^{\prime}â‰¤ roman_exp ( italic_Ïµ ) roman_Pr [ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] + italic_Î´ + italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT
â‰¤expâ¡(Ïµ)â¢Prâ¡[ğ’œÂ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿâ€²)âˆˆâ„°]+Î´+4â¢Î´â€².absentitalic-ÏµPrÂ¯ğ’œsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²â„°ğ›¿4superscriptğ›¿â€²\displaystyle\leq\exp\left(\epsilon\right)\Pr\left[\overline{\mathcal{A}}(% \mathcal{D}^{\prime})\in\mathcal{E}\right]+\delta+4\delta^{\prime}.â‰¤ roman_exp ( italic_Ïµ ) roman_Pr [ overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) âˆˆ caligraphic_E ] + italic_Î´ + 4 italic_Î´ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The first and last lines used the assumption between ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, and the second line used that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is DP. âˆ

We next recall the following well-known result on detecting the first large element in a stream.

Lemma 2 (Theorems 3.23, 3.24, [DR14]).

ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold is (Ïµ,0)italic-Ïµ0(\epsilon,0)( italic_Ïµ , 0 )-DP. Moreover, for Î³âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¾01\gamma\in(0,1)italic_Î³ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ), let Î±=8â¢Î”â¢logâ¡(2â¢TÎ³)Ïµğ›¼8Î”2ğ‘‡ğ›¾italic-Ïµ\alpha=\frac{8\Delta\log(\frac{2T}{\gamma})}{\epsilon}italic_Î± = divide start_ARG 8 roman_Î” roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î³ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG and ğ’Ÿâˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold halts at time kâˆˆ[T+1]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘‡1k\in[T+1]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_T + 1 ] such that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î³absent1ğ›¾\geq 1-\gammaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î³:

  • â€¢

    at=âŠ¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡bottoma_{t}=\botitalic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âŠ¥ and qtâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)â‰¤Ï„+Î±subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ’Ÿğœğ›¼q_{t}(\mathcal{D})\leq\tau+\alphaitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) â‰¤ italic_Ï„ + italic_Î± for all t<kğ‘¡ğ‘˜t<kitalic_t < italic_k.

  • â€¢

    ak=âŠ¤subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜topa_{k}=\topitalic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = âŠ¤ and qkâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)â‰¥Ï„âˆ’Î±subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜ğ’Ÿğœğ›¼q_{k}(\mathcal{D})\geq\tau-\alphaitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) â‰¥ italic_Ï„ - italic_Î± or k=T+1ğ‘˜ğ‘‡1k=T+1italic_k = italic_T + 1.

Finally, our developments in SectionÂ 4 use the notions of RÃ©nyi DP (RDP) and central DP (CDP). We provide a self-contained summary of the definitions and properties satisfied by RDP and CDP here, but refer the reader to [BS16, Mir17] for a more detailed overview.

Definition 2 (RDP and CDP).

Let Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1italic_Î± â‰¥ 1, Ïâ‰¥0ğœŒ0\rho\geq 0italic_Ï â‰¥ 0. We say that a randomized algorithm ğ’œ:ğ’³nâ†’Î©:ğ’œâ†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›Î©\mathcal{A}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omegacaligraphic_A : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© satisfies (Î±,Ï)ğ›¼ğœŒ(\alpha,\rho)( italic_Î± , italic_Ï )-RÃ©nyi differential privacy (or, is (Î±,Ï)ğ›¼ğœŒ(\alpha,\rho)( italic_Î± , italic_Ï )-RDP) if for all neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ’³nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’³ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

DÎ±â¢(ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆ¥ğ’œâ¢(ğ’Ÿâ€²))â‰¤Î±â¢Ï.subscriptğ·ğ›¼conditionalğ’œğ’Ÿğ’œsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğ›¼ğœŒD_{\alpha}(\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D})\|\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{D}^{\prime}))\leq% \alpha\rho.italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î± end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D ) âˆ¥ caligraphic_A ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) â‰¤ italic_Î± italic_Ï .

If this holds for all Î±â‰¥1ğ›¼1\alpha\geq 1italic_Î± â‰¥ 1, we say ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A satisfies ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï-central differential privacy (or, is ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï-CDP).

Fact 4 ([Mir17]).

RDP and CDP satisfy the following properties.

  1. 1.

    (Composition): If ğ’œ1:ğ’³nâ†’Î©1:subscriptğ’œ1â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›subscriptÎ©1\mathcal{A}_{1}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\Omega_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Î±,Ï1)ğ›¼subscriptğœŒ1(\alpha,\rho_{1})( italic_Î± , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-RDP and ğ’œ2:ğ’³nÃ—Î©1â†’Î©2:subscriptğ’œ2â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›subscriptÎ©1subscriptÎ©2\mathcal{A}_{2}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\times\Omega_{1}\to\Omega_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â†’ roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Î±,Ï2)ğ›¼subscriptğœŒ2(\alpha,\rho_{2})( italic_Î± , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for any fixed choice of input from Î©1subscriptÎ©1\Omega_{1}roman_Î© start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the composition of ğ’œ2subscriptğ’œ2\mathcal{A}_{2}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ’œ1subscriptğ’œ1\mathcal{A}_{1}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is (Î±,Ï1+Ï2)ğ›¼subscriptğœŒ1subscriptğœŒ2(\alpha,\rho_{1}+\rho_{2})( italic_Î± , italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Ï start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )-RDP.

  2. 2.

    (RDP to DP): If ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (Î±,Ï)ğ›¼ğœŒ(\alpha,\rho)( italic_Î± , italic_Ï )-RDP, it is also (Î±â¢Ï+1Î±âˆ’1â¢logâ¡1Î´,Î´)ğ›¼ğœŒ1ğ›¼11ğ›¿ğ›¿(\alpha\rho+\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\frac{1}{\delta},\delta)( italic_Î± italic_Ï + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î± - 1 end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG , italic_Î´ )-DP for all Î´âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¿01\delta\in(0,1)italic_Î´ âˆˆ ( 0 , 1 ).

  3. 3.

    (Gaussian mechanism): Let ğ¯:ğ’³nâ†’â„k:ğ¯â†’superscriptğ’³ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘˜\mathbf{v}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\to\mathbb{R}^{k}bold_v : caligraphic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have sensitivity Î”Î”\Deltaroman_Î”. Then for any Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0italic_Ïƒ > 0, drawing a sample from ğ’©â¢(ğ¯â¢(ğ’Ÿ),Ïƒ2â¢ğˆk)ğ’©ğ¯ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğˆğ‘˜\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{v}(\mathcal{D}),\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I}_{k})caligraphic_N ( bold_v ( caligraphic_D ) , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is Î”22â¢Ïƒ2superscriptÎ”22superscriptğœ2\frac{\Delta^{2}}{2\sigma^{2}}divide start_ARG roman_Î” start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG-CDP.

2.3 Geometric median

Throughout the rest of the paper, for a parameter R>0ğ‘…0R>0italic_R > 0, we fix a dataset ğ’Ÿ:={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚ğ”¹dâ¢(R)assignğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ), i.e., with domain ğ’³:=ğ”¹dâ¢(R)assignğ’³superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{X}:=\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_X := roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ). Our goal is to approximate the geometric median of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, i.e.,

ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ):=argâ¡minğ±âˆˆâ„dâ¡fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±),Â whereÂ â¢fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±):=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥formulae-sequenceassignsubscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ±assignÂ whereÂ subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ±1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–\displaystyle\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}):=\arg\min_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R% }^{d}}f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}),\text{ where }f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}):=% \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVertbold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) , where italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ (3)

is the average Euclidean distance to the dataset. Following e.g., [CLM+16, HSU24], we also define the quantile radii associated with our dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D centered at ğ±Â¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by

r(Ï„)â¢(ğ’Ÿ;ğ±Â¯):=argâ¡minrâ‰¥0â¡{âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±Â¯âˆ¥â‰¤râ‰¥Ï„â¢n},Â for allÂ â¢Ï„âˆˆ[0,1].formulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğœğ’ŸÂ¯ğ±subscriptğ‘Ÿ0subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–Â¯ğ±ğ‘Ÿğœğ‘›Â for allÂ ğœ01r^{(\tau)}(\mathcal{D};\bar{\mathbf{x}}):=\arg\min_{r\geq 0}\left\{\sum_{i\in[% n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\bar{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq r}% \geq\tau n\right\},\text{ for all }\tau\in[0,1].italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ; overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) := roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_Ï„ italic_n } , for all italic_Ï„ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] . (4)

In other words, r(Ï„)â¢(ğ’Ÿ;ğ±Â¯)superscriptğ‘Ÿğœğ’ŸÂ¯ğ±r^{(\tau)}(\mathcal{D};\bar{\mathbf{x}})italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ; overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG ) is the smallest radius râ‰¥0ğ‘Ÿ0r\geq 0italic_r â‰¥ 0 such that ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±Â¯,r)superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘Â¯ğ±ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},r)roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , italic_r ) contains at least a Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ fraction of the points in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. When ğ±Â¯Â¯ğ±\bar{\mathbf{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG is unspecified, we always assume by default that ğ±Â¯=ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ)Â¯ğ±subscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿ\bar{\mathbf{x}}=\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ).

In our utility analysis we will often suppress the dependence on ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D in ğ±â‹†,r(Ï„)subscriptğ±â‹†superscriptğ‘Ÿğœ\mathbf{x}_{\star},r^{(\tau)}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, etc., as the dataset of interest will not change. In the privacy analysis, we specify the dependence of these functions on the dataset explicitly when comparing algorithms run on neighboring datasets.

Finally, we include two helper results from prior work that are frequently used throughout.

Lemma 3.

Let ğ’Ÿ:={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚â„dassignğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)â‰¥(1âˆ’Ï„)â¢r(Ï„)subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†1ğœsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğœf_{\mathcal{D}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right)\geq(1-\tau)r^{(\tau)}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ ( 1 - italic_Ï„ ) italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Ï„ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all Ï„âˆˆ[0,1]ğœ01\tau\in[0,1]italic_Ï„ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

Proof.

This is immediate from the definition of fğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿf_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and nonnegativity of each summand âˆ¥â‹…âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVertâˆ¥ â‹… - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥. âˆ

Lemma 4 (Lemma 24, [CLM+16]).

Let ğ’Ÿ:={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚â„dassignğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and let SâŠ†[n]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘›S\subseteq[n]italic_S âŠ† [ italic_n ] have |S|<n2ğ‘†ğ‘›2|S|<\frac{n}{2}| italic_S | < divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Then,

âˆ¥ğ±â‹†âˆ’ğ±âˆ¥â‰¤(2â¢nâˆ’2â¢|S|nâˆ’2â¢|S|)â¢maxiâˆ‰Sâ¡â€–ğ±iâˆ’ğ±â€–,Â for allÂ â¢ğ±âˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencedelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±â‹†ğ±2ğ‘›2ğ‘†ğ‘›2ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–ğ‘†normsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ±Â for allÂ ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}\right\rVert\leq\left(\frac{2n-2|S|}{n% -2|S|}\right)\max_{i\notin S}\|\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}\|,\text{ for all }% \mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x âˆ¥ â‰¤ ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_n - 2 | italic_S | end_ARG start_ARG italic_n - 2 | italic_S | end_ARG ) roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆ‰ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x âˆ¥ , for all bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

3 Constant-Factor Approximation

In this section, we give our first main result: a fast algorithm for computing a constant-factor approximation to the geometric median. Our approach is to speed up several of the steps in the initial two phases of the [HSU24] algorithm via subsampling and techniques inspired by the FriendlyCore framework of [TCK+22]. Specifically, in SectionÂ 3.1, we first show how AlgorithmÂ 1 can be sped up using subsampled scores, to estimate quantile radii up to constant factors in nearly-linear time, improving Section 2.1 of [HSU24]. In SectionÂ 3.2, we then adapt a weighted variant of FriendlyCore to give a simple algorithm for approximate centerpoint computation, improving Section 2.2 of [HSU24] for large aspect ratios.

3.1 Radius estimation

In this section, we present and analyze our radius estimation algorithm.

AlgorithmÂ 2 is clearly an instance of AlgorithmÂ 1 with Î”=3Î”3\Delta=3roman_Î” = 3, where the queries are given on LineÂ 11. However, one subtlety is that the queries in AlgorithmÂ 2 have random sensitivities depending on the subsampled sets on LineÂ 8. Nonetheless, we show that Chernoff bounds control this sensitivity with high probability, which yields privacy upon applying LemmaÂ 2.

Lemma 5.

AlgorithmÂ 2 is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP.

Proof.

Fix neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ”¹dâ¢(R)nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss that they differ in the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. Observe that ğ–¥ğ–ºğ—Œğ—ğ–±ğ–ºğ–½ğ—‚ğ—ğ—Œğ–¥ğ–ºğ—Œğ—ğ–±ğ–ºğ–½ğ—‚ğ—ğ—Œ\mathsf{FastRadius}sansserif_FastRadius (independently) uses randomness in two places: the random subsets in LineÂ 8, and the Laplace noise added as in the original ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½ğ– ğ–»ğ—ˆğ—ğ–¾ğ–³ğ—ğ—‹ğ–¾ğ—Œğ—ğ—ˆğ—…ğ–½\mathsf{AboveThreshold}sansserif_AboveThreshold algorithm in LinesÂ 4 andÂ 12.

We next claim that in any iteration tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ], as long as the number of copies of the index nğ‘›nitalic_n occurring in â‹ƒiâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]St(i)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘–\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is at most 2â¢k2ğ‘˜2k2 italic_k, then the sensitivity of the query qtsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡q_{t}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is at most 3333. To see this, denoting by qt,qtâ€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡â€²q_{t},q_{t}^{\prime}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the random queries when AlgorithmÂ 2 is run on ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively, and similarly defining {Nt(i),(Nt(i))â€²}iâˆˆ[n]subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€²ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\{N_{t}^{(i)},(N_{t}^{(i)})^{\prime}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we observe that the sensitivity is controlled as follows:

qtâˆ’qtâ€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¡\displaystyle q_{t}-q^{\prime}_{t}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nâˆ’1](Nt(i)âˆ’(Nt(i))â€²)+nnabsent1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–â€²ğ‘›ğ‘›\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n-1]}\left(N_{t}^{(i)}-\left(N_{t}^{(i)% }\right)^{\prime}\right)+\frac{n}{n}â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG
â‰¤1nâ‹…nkâ‹…(number of copies ofÂ â¢nâ¢Â occurring inÂ â¢â‹ƒiâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]St(i))+1â‰¤3.absentâ‹…1ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘˜number of copies ofÂ ğ‘›Â occurring inÂ subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘–13\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{n}\cdot\frac{n}{k}\cdot\left(\text{number of copies % of }n\text{ occurring in }\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}\right)+1\leq 3.â‰¤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG â‹… divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_k end_ARG â‹… ( number of copies of italic_n occurring in â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 1 â‰¤ 3 .

The first line holds because the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (neighboring) point has Nt(n)â‰¤nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘›N_{t}^{(n)}\leq nitalic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_n and (Nt(n))â€²â‰¥0superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘›â€²0(N_{t}^{(n)})^{\prime}\geq 0( italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0; the second is because every ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±jâˆ¥â‰¤rtsubscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq r_{t}}roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT used in the computation of Nt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡ğ‘–N_{t}^{(i)}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is coupled except when j=nğ‘—ğ‘›j=nitalic_j = italic_n is sampled.

Now, let ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG denote AlgorithmÂ 2, and let ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A denote a variant that conditions on the randomly-sampled â‹ƒiâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]St(i)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘–\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT containing at most 2â¢k2ğ‘˜2k2 italic_k copies of the index nğ‘›nitalic_n, in all encountered iterations tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ]. By using FactÂ 1 (with Î¼â†kâ‹…nâˆ’1nâ†ğœ‡â‹…ğ‘˜ğ‘›1ğ‘›\mu\leftarrow k\cdot\frac{n-1}{n}italic_Î¼ â† italic_k â‹… divide start_ARG italic_n - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG, Ïµâ†1â†italic-Ïµ1\epsilon\leftarrow 1italic_Ïµ â† 1), due to our choice of kğ‘˜kitalic_k, â‹ƒiâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]St(i)subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1superscriptsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡ğ‘–\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{t}^{(i)}â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_i ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains at most 2â¢k2ğ‘˜2k2 italic_k copies of nğ‘›nitalic_n except with probability Î´4â¢Tğ›¿4ğ‘‡\frac{\delta}{4T}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG, so by a union bound, the total variation distance between ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG and ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is at most Î´4ğ›¿4\frac{\delta}{4}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG. Moreover, ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (Ïµ,0)italic-Ïµ0(\epsilon,0)( italic_Ïµ , 0 )-DP by using LemmaÂ 2. Thus, ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP using LemmaÂ 1. âˆ

We are now ready to prove a utility and runtime guarantee on AlgorithmÂ 2.

Lemma 6.

AlgorithmÂ 2 runs in time Oâ¢(nâ¢dâ¢logâ¡(Rr)â¢logâ¡(logâ¡(Rr)â¢1Î´))ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘…ğ‘Ÿğ‘…ğ‘Ÿ1ğ›¿O(nd\log(\frac{R}{r})\log(\log(\frac{R}{r})\frac{1}{\delta}))italic_O ( italic_n italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) roman_log ( roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_R end_ARG start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) ). Moreover, if râ‰¤4â¢r(0.9)ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}italic_r â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and nâ‰¥2400Ïµâ¢logâ¡(4â¢TÎ´)ğ‘›2400italic-Ïµ4ğ‘‡ğ›¿n\geq\frac{2400}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4T}{\delta})italic_n â‰¥ divide start_ARG 2400 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ), with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´, AlgorithmÂ 2 outputs r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG satisfying 14â¢r(0.75)â‰¤r^â‰¤4â¢r(0.9)14superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.75^ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9\frac{1}{4}r^{(0.75)}\leq\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

The first claim is immediate. To see the second, for all tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ] denote the â€œidealâ€ query by:

qtâ‹†:=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]âˆ‘jâˆˆ[n]ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±jâˆ¥â‰¤rt,assignsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡q^{\star}_{t}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq r_{t}},italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and recall ğ”¼â¢qt=qtâ‹†ğ”¼subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡\mathbb{E}q_{t}=q^{\star}_{t}roman_ğ”¼ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our first claim is that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´2absent1ğ›¿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, the following guarantees hold for all iterations tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ] that AlgorithmÂ 2 completes:

qtâ‹†>0.8â¢nâŸ¹qt>0.79â¢n,Â andÂ â¢qtâ‹†<0.75â¢nâŸ¹qt<0.76â¢n.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡0.8ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡0.79ğ‘›Â andÂ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡0.75ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡0.76ğ‘›q^{\star}_{t}>0.8n\implies q_{t}>0.79n,\text{ and }q^{\star}_{t}<0.75n\implies q% _{t}<0.76n.italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.8 italic_n âŸ¹ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.79 italic_n , and italic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.75 italic_n âŸ¹ italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.76 italic_n . (5)
