expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµ2â¢Î¼2+Ïµ)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµ2â¢Î¼151â¢Ïµ)=expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµâ¢Î¼151)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’n215100)â‰¤Î´2â¢Tsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğœ‡2italic-Ïµsuperscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğœ‡151italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğœ‡151superscriptğ‘›215100ğ›¿2ğ‘‡\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon^{2}\mu}{151\epsilon}\right)=\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon\mu}{151}\right)% \leq\exp\left(-\frac{n^{2}}{15100}\right)\leq\frac{\delta}{2T}roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 151 italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) = roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 151 end_ARG ) â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 15100 end_ARG ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_T end_ARG (6)

for the relevant range of nğ‘›nitalic_n and Ïµâ‰¥175italic-Ïµ175\epsilon\geq\frac{1}{75}italic_Ïµ â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG, Ïµâ¢Î¼â‰¥n2100italic-Ïµğœ‡superscriptğ‘›2100\epsilon\mu\geq\frac{n^{2}}{100}italic_Ïµ italic_Î¼ â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG. We thus obtain (5) after a union bound over all tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ].

Now, suppose that tâˆˆ[T]ğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡t\in[T]italic_t âˆˆ [ italic_T ] is the first index where qt+Î½tâ‰¥Ï„^subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğœˆğ‘¡^ğœq_{t}+\nu_{t}\geq\hat{\tau}italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î½ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ over^ start_ARG italic_Ï„ end_ARG, so that r^=rt^ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡\hat{r}=r_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 12â¢r^=rtâˆ’112^ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘¡1\frac{1}{2}\hat{r}=r_{t-1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where we let r0:=r2assignsubscriptğ‘Ÿ0ğ‘Ÿ2r_{0}:=\frac{r}{2}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. If no such query passes, then we set t=T+1ğ‘¡ğ‘‡1t=T+1italic_t = italic_T + 1 by default. Then by the utility guarantees of LemmaÂ 6, we have that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´2absent1ğ›¿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG,

qtâ‰¥0.76â¢n,qtâˆ’1â‰¤0.79â¢n,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡0.76ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡10.79ğ‘›\displaystyle q_{t}\geq 0.76n,\;q_{t-1}\leq 0.79n,italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.76 italic_n , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.79 italic_n ,

since n100â‰¥Î±=24Ïµâ¢logâ¡(4â¢TÎ´)ğ‘›100ğ›¼24italic-Ïµ4ğ‘‡ğ›¿\frac{n}{100}\geq\alpha=\frac{24}{\epsilon}\log(\frac{4T}{\delta})divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG â‰¥ italic_Î± = divide start_ARG 24 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) . By taking the contrapositive of (5), we can conclude that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´, we have qtâ‹†â‰¥0.75â¢nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡0.75ğ‘›q^{\star}_{t}\geq 0.75nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.75 italic_n and qtâˆ’1â‹†â‰¤0.8â¢nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡10.8ğ‘›q^{\star}_{t-1}\leq 0.8nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.8 italic_n. Condition on this event for the rest of the proof.

Because qtâ‹†â‰¥0.75â¢nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡â‹†0.75ğ‘›q_{t}^{\star}\geq 0.75nitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.75 italic_n, there is clearly some ğ±iâˆˆğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ’Ÿ\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D such that |ğ’Ÿâˆ©ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±i,r^)|â‰¥0.75â¢nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ±ğ‘–^ğ‘Ÿ0.75ğ‘›|\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r})|\geq 0.75n| caligraphic_D âˆ© roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) | â‰¥ 0.75 italic_n, as this is the average number of dataset elements in a radius-r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ball centered at a random ğ±âˆˆğ’Ÿğ±ğ’Ÿ\mathbf{x}\in\mathcal{D}bold_x âˆˆ caligraphic_D. Now applying LemmaÂ 4 with Sğ‘†Sitalic_S set to the indices of ğ’Ÿâˆ–ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±i,r^)ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ±ğ‘–^ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{D}\setminus\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r})caligraphic_D âˆ– roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), so that |S|â‰¤0.25â¢nğ‘†0.25ğ‘›|S|\leq 0.25n| italic_S | â‰¤ 0.25 italic_n, gives

âˆ¥ğ±â‹†âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥â‰¤3â¢r^âŸ¹âˆ¥ğ±â‹†âˆ’ğ±jâˆ¥â‰¤4â¢r^â¢Â for allÂ â¢ğ±jâˆˆğ’Ÿâˆ©ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±i,r^).delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ±ğ‘–3^ğ‘Ÿdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±â‹†subscriptğ±ğ‘—4^ğ‘ŸÂ for allÂ subscriptğ±ğ‘—ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ±ğ‘–^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert\leq 3\hat{r}\implies% \left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq 4\hat{r}\text{ % for all }\mathbf{x}_{j}\in\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{i},\hat{r}).âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG âŸ¹ âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG for all bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D âˆ© roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) .

This implies 4â¢r^â‰¥r(0.75)4^ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.754\hat{r}\geq r^{(0.75)}4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG â‰¥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as claimed. Further, because qtâˆ’1â‹†â‰¤0.8â¢nsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘¡1â‹†0.8ğ‘›q_{t-1}^{\star}\leq 0.8nitalic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.8 italic_n, we claim r^2>2â¢r(0.9)^ğ‘Ÿ22superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9\frac{\hat{r}}{2}>2r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG > 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cannot hold. Assume for contradiction that this happened, and let S:=ğ’Ÿâˆ©ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±â‹†,r(0.9))assignğ‘†ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘subscriptğ±â‹†superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9S:=\mathcal{D}\cap\mathbb{B}^{d}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},r^{(0.9)})italic_S := caligraphic_D âˆ© roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). By the triangle inequality, for all of the 0.9â¢n0.9ğ‘›0.9n0.9 italic_n choices of ğ±iâˆˆSsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘†\mathbf{x}_{i}\in Sbold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ italic_S, we have that

âˆ‘jâˆˆ[n]ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±jâˆ¥â‰¤r^2â‰¥0.9â¢n,subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—^ğ‘Ÿ20.9ğ‘›\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert% \leq\frac{\hat{r}}{2}}\geq 0.9n,âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.9 italic_n ,

which implies that qtâˆ’1â‹†â‰¥0.81â¢nsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘â‹†ğ‘¡10.81ğ‘›q^{\star}_{t-1}\geq 0.81nitalic_q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.81 italic_n, a contradiction. Thus, we obtain r^â‰¤4â¢r(0.9)^ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well.

We remark that all of this logic handles the case where 2â‰¤tâ‰¤T2ğ‘¡ğ‘‡2\leq t\leq T2 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ italic_T is the iteration where AlgorithmÂ 2 returns. However, it is straightforward to check that the conclusion holds when t=1ğ‘¡1t=1italic_t = 1 (i.e., r^=r^ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}=rover^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_r) because we assumed râ‰¤4â¢r(0.9)ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}italic_r â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the lower bound logic on r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is the same as before. Similarly, if r^=R^ğ‘Ÿğ‘…\hat{r}=Rover^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_R, then the upper bound logic on r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG is the same as before, and 2â¢Râ‰¥r(1)â‰¥r(0.75)â‰¥24â¢r(0.75)2ğ‘…superscriptğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.7524superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.752R\geq r^{(1)}\geq r^{(0.75)}\geq\frac{2}{4}r^{(0.75)}2 italic_R â‰¥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¥ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is clear. âˆ

In summary, LemmasÂ 5 andÂ 6 show that we can privately estimate r^^ğ‘Ÿ\hat{r}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG satisfying 14â¢r(0.75)â‰¤r^â‰¤4â¢r(0.9)14superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.75^ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9\frac{1}{4}r^{(0.75)}\leq\hat{r}\leq 4r^{(0.9)}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in nearly-linear time. The upper bound implies (with LemmaÂ 3) that r^=Oâ¢(fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†))^ğ‘Ÿğ‘‚subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†\hat{r}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}))over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ); on the other hand, the lower bound will be critically used in our centerpoint estimation procedure in SectionÂ 3.2.

3.2 Centerpoint estimation

In this section, we combine the subsampling strategies used in SectionÂ 3.1 with a simplification of the FriendlyCore framework [TCK+22] to obtain a private estimate of an approximate centerpoint.

To briefly explain, AlgorithmÂ 3 outputs a noisy weighted average of the dataset. The weights {pi}iâˆˆ[n]subscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\{p_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}{ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT linearly interpolate estimated scores fiâˆˆ[0.5â¢k,0.75â¢k]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.5ğ‘˜0.75ğ‘˜f_{i}\in[0.5k,0.75k]italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ [ 0.5 italic_k , 0.75 italic_k ] into the range [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], sending fiâ‰¥0.75â¢ksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.75ğ‘˜f_{i}\geq 0.75kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.75 italic_k to 1111, and fiâ‰¤0.5â¢ksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.5ğ‘˜f_{i}\leq 0.5kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.5 italic_k to 00. We first make some basic observations about the points that contribute positively to the weighted combination ğ±Â¯Â¯ğ±\bar{\mathbf{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG, based on binomial concentration.

Lemma 7.

Assume that r^â‰¥r(0.75)^ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.75\hat{r}\geq r^{(0.75)}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG â‰¥ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the context of AlgorithmÂ 3. With probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´18absent1ğ›¿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, every iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] that is assigned pi>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 in AlgorithmÂ 3 satisfies âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±â‹†âˆ¥â‰¤3â¢r^delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±â‹†3^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq 3\hat{r}âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG, and Zâ‰¥0.6â¢nğ‘0.6ğ‘›Z\geq 0.6nitalic_Z â‰¥ 0.6 italic_n.

Proof.

Our proof is analogous to LemmaÂ 6, where for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] we define the â€œideal scoreâ€

fiâ‹†:=knâ¢âˆ‘jâˆˆ[n]ğ•€âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±jâˆ¥â‰¤2â¢r^,assignsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›subscriptğ•€delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘—2^ğ‘Ÿf^{\star}_{i}:=\frac{k}{n}\sum_{j\in[n]}\mathbb{I}_{\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-% \mathbf{x}_{j}\right\rVert\leq 2\hat{r}},italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

such that ğ”¼â¢fi=fiâ‹†ğ”¼subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–\mathbb{E}f_{i}=f^{\star}_{i}roman_ğ”¼ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We first claim that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´18absent1ğ›¿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, the following hold for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]:

fiâ‹†â‰¥0.75â¢kâŸ¹fiâ‰¥0.7â¢k,Â andÂ â¢fiâ‹†â‰¤0.45â¢kâŸ¹fiâ‰¤0.5â¢k.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.75ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.7ğ‘˜Â andÂ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.45ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.5ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{i}\geq 0.75k\implies f_{i}\geq 0.7k,\text{ and }f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0% .45k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.5k.italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.75 italic_k âŸ¹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.7 italic_k , and italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.45 italic_k âŸ¹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.5 italic_k . (7)

The first claim above is immediate from our choice of kğ‘˜kitalic_k and FactÂ 1 (with failure probability â‰¤Î´18â¢nabsentğ›¿18ğ‘›\leq\frac{\delta}{18n}â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 italic_n end_ARG for each iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]); the second follows (with the same failure probability) similarly to (6), i.e.,

expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµ2â¢Î¼2+Ïµ)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’Ïµâ¢Î¼20)â‰¤expâ¡(âˆ’k400)â‰¤Î´18â¢n,superscriptitalic-Ïµ2ğœ‡2italic-Ïµitalic-Ïµğœ‡20ğ‘˜400ğ›¿18ğ‘›\exp\left(-\frac{\epsilon^{2}\mu}{2+\epsilon}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{% \epsilon\mu}{20}\right)\leq\exp\left(-\frac{k}{400}\right)\leq\frac{\delta}{18% n},roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 2 + italic_Ïµ end_ARG ) â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ italic_Î¼ end_ARG start_ARG 20 end_ARG ) â‰¤ roman_exp ( - divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 400 end_ARG ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 italic_n end_ARG ,

in our application, with Ïµâ‰¥19italic-Ïµ19\epsilon\geq\frac{1}{9}italic_Ïµ â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG and Ïµâ¢Î¼â‰¥k20italic-Ïµğœ‡ğ‘˜20\epsilon\mu\geq\frac{k}{20}italic_Ïµ italic_Î¼ â‰¥ divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 20 end_ARG. Thus a union bound proves (7).

To obtain the first claim, observe that any iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] with âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±â‹†âˆ¥>3â¢r^delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±â‹†3^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert>3\hat{r}âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ > 3 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG must have that ğ”¹â¢(ğ±i,2â¢r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘–2^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) does not intersect ğ”¹â¢(ğ±â‹†,r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±â‹†^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). However, ğ”¹â¢(ğ±â‹†,r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±â‹†^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{\star},\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains 0.75â¢n0.75ğ‘›0.75n0.75 italic_n points in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by assumption, so fiâ‹†â‰¤0.25â¢ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.25ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0.25kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.25 italic_k and thus as long as the implication (7) holds, then pi=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0p_{i}=0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 as desired. For the second claim, any ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfying âˆ¥ğ±iâˆ’ğ±â‹†âˆ¥â‰¤r(0.75)delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ±â‹†superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.75\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{i}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}\right\rVert\leq r^{(0.75)}âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.75 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has |ğ”¹â¢(ğ±i,2â¢r^)âˆ©ğ’Ÿ|â‰¥0.75â¢nğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘–2^ğ‘Ÿğ’Ÿ0.75ğ‘›|\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})\cap\mathcal{D}|\geq 0.75n| roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) âˆ© caligraphic_D | â‰¥ 0.75 italic_n, so that fiâ‹†â‰¥0.7â¢ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.7ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{i}\geq 0.7kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0.7 italic_k. We next observe that whenever the algorithm does not return on LineÂ 10, all surviving points (i.e., with pi>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0) must lie in a ball of diameter Oâ¢(r^)ğ‘‚^ğ‘ŸO(\hat{r})italic_O ( over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), under a high-probability event over our subsampled scores. Lemma 8.

Suppose that it is the case that in the context of AlgorithmÂ 3, we have

fiâ‹†â‰¤0.45â¢kâŸ¹fiâ‰¤0.5â¢k,Â andÂ â¢fiâ‹†â‰¤0.55â¢kâŸ¹fiâ‰¤0.6â¢k,formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.45ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.5ğ‘˜Â andÂ subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.55ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–0.6ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0.45k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.5k,\text{ and }f^{\star}_{i}\leq 0% .55k\implies f_{i}\leq 0.6k,italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.45 italic_k âŸ¹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.5 italic_k , and italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.55 italic_k âŸ¹ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ 0.6 italic_k , (8)

for all iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. If Z>0.55â¢nğ‘0.55ğ‘›Z>0.55nitalic_Z > 0.55 italic_n, there exists some ğ±âˆˆâ„dğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that {ğ±iâˆ£pi>0}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ†ğ”¹â¢(ğ±,4â¢r^)subscriptconditional-setsubscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›ğ”¹ğ±4^ğ‘Ÿ\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\mid p_{i}>0\}_{i\in[n]}\subseteq\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x},4\hat{r}){ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ† roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x , 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). Moreover, the event (8) occurs with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´9absent1ğ›¿9\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{9}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG.

Proof.

The first statement in (8) was proven in (7) to hold with probability Î´18ğ›¿18\frac{\delta}{18}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG, and the second statementâ€™s proof is identical to the first half up to changing constants, so we omit it. Conditioned on this event, every ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with pi>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0p_{i}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 has fiâ‹†>0.45â¢ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘–0.45ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{i}>0.45kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.45 italic_k. Moreover, because Z>0.55â¢nğ‘0.55ğ‘›Z>0.55nitalic_Z > 0.55 italic_n, there exists some jâˆˆ[n]ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘›j\in[n]italic_j âˆˆ [ italic_n ] (i.e., with the maximum value of pjsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—p_{j}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) such that pj>0.55subscriptğ‘ğ‘—0.55p_{j}>0.55italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.55, which implies fj>0.6â¢ksubscriptğ‘“ğ‘—0.6ğ‘˜f_{j}>0.6kitalic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.6 italic_k and thus fjâ‹†>0.55â¢ksubscriptsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘—0.55ğ‘˜f^{\star}_{j}>0.55kitalic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0.55 italic_k.

So, we have shown that ğ”¹â¢(ğ±j,2â¢r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘—2^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},2\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains more than 0.55â¢n0.55ğ‘›0.55n0.55 italic_n points in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, and every surviving iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] (i.e., with positive pisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) contains more than 0.45â¢n0.45ğ‘›0.45n0.45 italic_n points in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D. Thus, ğ”¹â¢(ğ±j,2â¢r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘—2^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},2\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) and ğ”¹â¢(ğ±i,2â¢r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘–2^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{i},2\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 2 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) intersect, and in particular, ğ”¹â¢(ğ±j,4â¢r^)ğ”¹subscriptğ±ğ‘—4^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}(\mathbf{x}_{j},4\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) contains every surviving point by the triangle inequality. âˆ

We are now ready to prove a privacy bound on AlgorithmÂ 3.

Lemma 9.

If nâ‰¥20ğ‘›20n\geq 20italic_n â‰¥ 20, AlgorithmÂ 3 is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP.

Proof.

Fix neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆğ”¹dâ¢(R)nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘…ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss that they differ in the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry ğ±nâ‰ ğ±nâ€²subscriptğ±ğ‘›subscriptsuperscriptğ±â€²ğ‘›\mathbf{x}_{n}\neq\mathbf{x}^{\prime}_{n}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰  bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will define ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, an alternate variant of AlgorithmÂ 3, which we denote ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG, where we condition on the following two events occurring. First, the index nğ‘›nitalic_n should occur at most 2â¢k2ğ‘˜2k2 italic_k times in â‹ƒiâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]Sisubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–\bigcup_{i\in[n-1]}S_{i}â‹ƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Second, the implications (8) must hold. It is clear that the first described event occurs with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´18absent1ğ›¿18\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{18}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 18 end_ARG by using FactÂ 1 with our choice of kğ‘˜kitalic_k, and we proved in LemmaÂ 8 that the second described event occurs with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´9absent1ğ›¿9\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{9}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG. Thus, the total variation distance between ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is at most Î´6ğ›¿6\frac{\delta}{6}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG. We will prove that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (Ïµ,Î´3)italic-Ïµğ›¿3(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{3})( italic_Ïµ , divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG )-DP, from which LemmaÂ 1 gives that ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP.

The first line shifted both ğ±Â¯Â¯ğ±\bar{\mathbf{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG and ğ±Â¯â€²superscriptÂ¯ğ±â€²\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{\prime}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by ğ±^^ğ±\hat{\mathbf{x}}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG, and the second line applied the triangle inequality. The third line applied the triangle inequality to the middle term, and bounded the contribution of ğ²nsubscriptğ²ğ‘›\mathbf{y}_{n}bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by using that âˆ¥ğ²nâˆ¥â‰¤8â¢r^delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ²ğ‘›8^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{y}_{n}\right\rVert\leq 8\hat{r}âˆ¥ bold_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG if pn>0subscriptğ‘ğ‘›0p_{n}>0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0; a similar bound applies to ğ²nâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ²â€²ğ‘›\mathbf{y}^{\prime}_{n}bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In the fourth line, we used the triangle inequality on the first term, as well as that âˆ‘iâˆˆ[nâˆ’1]|piâˆ’piâ€²|â‰¤1+12subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘–112\sum_{i\in[n-1]}|p_{i}-p^{\prime}_{i}|\leq 1+12âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n - 1 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | â‰¤ 1 + 12 by using (9) and accounting for the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT point separately. Thus, ğ±Â¯Â¯ğ±\bar{\mathbf{x}}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG has sensitivity 400â¢r^n400^ğ‘Ÿğ‘›\frac{400\hat{r}}{n}divide start_ARG 400 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG in ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A. FactÂ 2 now guarantees that LineÂ 19 is also (Ïµ2,Î´6)italic-Ïµ2ğ›¿6(\frac{\epsilon}{2},\frac{\delta}{6})( divide start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG )-DP. âˆ

We now combine our developments to give our constant-factor approximation to the geometric median.

Theorem 3.

Let ğ’Ÿ={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]âŠ‚ğ”¹dâ¢(R)ğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘ğ‘…\mathcal{D}=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}\subset\mathbb{B}^{d}(R)caligraphic_D = { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ‚ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R ) for R>0ğ‘…0R>0italic_R > 0, let 0<râ‰¤4â¢r(0.9)â¢(ğ’Ÿ)0ğ‘Ÿ4superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9ğ’Ÿ0<r\leq 4r^{(0.9)}(\mathcal{D})0 < italic_r â‰¤ 4 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ), and let (Ïµ,Î´)âˆˆ[0,1]2italic-Ïµğ›¿superscript012(\epsilon,\delta)\in[0,1]^{2}( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ ) âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Suppose that

Proof.

The privacy of composing these two algorithms now follows from LemmasÂ 5 andÂ 9, and the runtime follows from LemmaÂ 6, because AlgorithmÂ 2â€™s runtime does not dominate upon inspection.

Thus, âˆ¥ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆ’ğ±^âˆ¥â‰¤Câ€²â¢r^delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿ^ğ±superscriptğ¶â€²^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\mathbf{x}}\right\rVert\leq C^% {\prime}\hat{r}âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) - over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG holds for an appropriate Câ€²superscriptğ¶â€²C^{\prime}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, except with probability Î´ğ›¿\deltaitalic_Î´. âˆ

We remark that TheoremÂ 3 actually comes with the slightly stronger guarantee that we obtain the optimal value for the geometric median objective fğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿf_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, up to an additive error scaling as Oâ¢(r(0.9))ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9O(r^{(0.9)})italic_O ( italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). In general, while r(0.9)=Oâ¢(fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ)))superscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿr^{(0.9)}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) ) is always true by LemmaÂ 3, it is possible that r(0.9)â‰ªfğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ))much-less-thansuperscriptğ‘Ÿ0.9subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿr^{(0.9)}\ll f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D}))italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.9 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ª italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) if a small fraction of outlier points contributes significantly to the objective. We also note that for datasets where we have more a priori information on the number of outliers we expect to see, we can adjust the quantile 0.90.90.90.9 in TheoremÂ 3 to be any quantile >0.5absent0.5>0.5> 0.5 by appropriately adjusting constants.

4 Boosting Approximations via Stable DP-SGD

In this section, we give a DP algorithm that efficiently minimizes the geometric median objective (3) over a domain ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±Â¯,r^)superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘Â¯ğ±^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ), given a dataset ğ’Ÿ:={ğ±i}iâˆˆ[n]assignğ’Ÿsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›\mathcal{D}:=\{\mathbf{x}_{i}\}_{i\in[n]}caligraphic_D := { bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In our final application to the geometric median problem, the optimization domain (i.e., the parameters ğ±Â¯âˆˆâ„dÂ¯ğ±superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bar{\mathbf{x}}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and r^âˆˆâ„â‰¥0^ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„absent0\hat{r}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) will be privately estimated using TheoremÂ 3, such that with high probability r^=Oâ¢(fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ)))^ğ‘Ÿğ‘‚subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿ\hat{r}=O(f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})))over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG = italic_O ( italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) ) ) and âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ±â‹†â¢(ğ’Ÿ)âˆ¥â‰¤r^delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±subscriptğ±â‹†ğ’Ÿ^ğ‘Ÿ\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}_{\star}(\mathcal{D})\right\rVert\leq\hat{r}âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_D ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG. In the meantime, we treat the domain ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±Â¯,r^)superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘Â¯ğ±^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) as a public input here.

Our strategy is to use a localization framework given by [FKT20], which gives a query-efficient reduction from private DP-SGD to stable DP-SGD executed in phases. Specifically, observe that outputting555By default, if ğ±=ğ±iğ±subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}=\mathbf{x}_{i}bold_x = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we let (12) evaluate to ğŸdsubscript0ğ‘‘\mathbf{0}_{d}bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a valid subgradient by first-order optimality.

ğ³âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥ğ³âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥=âˆ‡âˆ¥â‹…âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥(ğ³)\frac{\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right% \rVert}=\nabla\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert\left(\mathbf{z}\right)divide start_ARG bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG = âˆ‡ âˆ¥ â‹… - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ ( bold_z ) (12)

for a uniformly random iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] is unbiased for a subgradient of fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ³)subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ³f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{z})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z ). This leads us to define the following AlgorithmÂ 4 patterned off the [FKT20] framework, whose privacy is analyzed in SectionÂ 4.1 using a custom stability argument, and whose utility is analyzed in SectionÂ 4.2.

AlgorithmÂ 4 proceeds in Kâ‰ˆlogâ¡(T)ğ¾ğ‘‡K\approx\log(T)italic_K â‰ˆ roman_log ( italic_T ) phases. In each phase (loop of LinesÂ 2 toÂ 18) other than k=1ğ‘˜1k=1italic_k = 1, we define a domain ğ’¦(k)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘˜\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT centered at the output of the previous phase with geometrically shrinking radius âˆÏƒ(k)proportional-toabsentsuperscriptğœğ‘˜\propto\sigma^{(k)}âˆ italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the domain for phase k=1ğ‘˜1k=1italic_k = 1 is simply ğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±Â¯,r^)superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘Â¯ğ±^ğ‘Ÿ\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{x}},\hat{r})roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ). After this, we take T(k)superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜T^{(k)}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT steps of SGD over ğ’¦(k)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘˜\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with step size Î·(k)superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta^{(k)}italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and output a noised variant of the average iterate in LinesÂ 15 toÂ 17.

Remark 1.

Several steps in AlgorithmÂ 4 are used only in the worst-case utility proof, and do not affect privacy. Practical optimizations can be made while preserving privacy guarantees, e.g., removing projections onto the changing domains ğ’¦(k)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘˜\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rather than ğ’¦(1)superscriptğ’¦1\mathcal{K}^{(1)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is not used in the privacy proof.

One optimization we found useful in our experiments (described in SectionÂ 5) is replacing the random sampling on LineÂ 12 with deterministic passes through the dataset in a fixed order. By doing so, we know the total number of accesses of any single element is â‰¤m:=âŒˆTnâŒ‰absentğ‘šassignğ‘‡ğ‘›\leq m:=\lceil\frac{T}{n}\rceilâ‰¤ italic_m := âŒˆ divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âŒ‰ (rather than the high-probability estimate in LemmaÂ 10 for the randomized variant in AlgorithmÂ 4). This lets us tighten the noise level Ïƒ(k)superscriptğœğ‘˜\sigma^{(k)}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by a fairly significant constant factor, resulting in improved empirical performance.

4.1 Privacy of AlgorithmÂ 4

In this section, we show that AlgorithmÂ 4 satisfies (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP for an appropriate choice of ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï. When the sample functions of interest are smooth (i.e., have bounded second derivative), [FKT20] gives a proof based on the contractivity of iterates. This is based on the observation that gradient descent steps with respect to a smooth function are contractive for an appropriate step size (see e.g., Proposition 2.10, [FKT20]). Unfortunately, our sample functions are of the form âˆ¥â‹…âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥\left\lVert\cdot-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVertâˆ¥ â‹… - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥, which are not even differentiable, let alone smooth. Nonetheless, we inductively prove approximate contractivity of AlgorithmÂ 4â€™s iterates by opening up the analysis and using the structure of the geometric median objective.

Throughout, we fix neighboring ğ’Ÿ,ğ’Ÿâ€²âˆˆ(â„d)nğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘›\mathcal{D},\mathcal{D}^{\prime}\in(\mathbb{R}^{d})^{n}caligraphic_D , caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ ( roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume without loss of generality they differ in the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. To simplify notation, we let â„âˆˆ[n]Tâ„superscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘›ğ‘‡\mathcal{I}\in[n]^{T}caligraphic_I âˆˆ [ italic_n ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the multiset of Tğ‘‡Titalic_T indices sampled in LineÂ 12, across all phases. We prove DP of AlgorithmÂ 4 via appealing to LemmaÂ 1, where we let ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG denote AlgorithmÂ 4, and we let ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A denote a variant of AlgorithmÂ 4 conditioned on â„â„\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing at most m:=3â¢(Tn+logâ¡(8Î´))assignğ‘š3ğ‘‡ğ‘›8ğ›¿m:=3(\frac{T}{n}+\log(\frac{8}{\delta}))italic_m := 3 ( divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG + roman_log ( divide start_ARG 8 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) ) copies of nğ‘›nitalic_n. We first bound the total variation distance between ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG using FactÂ 1.

Lemma 10.

With probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´8absent1ğ›¿8\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{8}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG, AlgorithmÂ 4 yields â„â„\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing â‰¤mabsentğ‘š\leq mâ‰¤ italic_m copies of nğ‘›nitalic_n.

Proof.

In expectation, we have Tnâ‰¥1ğ‘‡ğ‘›1\frac{T}{n}\geq 1divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG â‰¥ 1 copies, so the result follows from FactÂ 1 and our choice of mğ‘šmitalic_m. âˆ

We will show that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (Ïµ,Î´2)italic-Ïµğ›¿2(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_Ïµ , divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )-DP, upon which LemmasÂ 1 andÂ 10 imply that ğ’œÂ¯Â¯ğ’œ\overline{\mathcal{A}}overÂ¯ start_ARG caligraphic_A end_ARG (AlgorithmÂ 4) is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP. To do so, we control the sensitivity of each iterate ğ³t(k)superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, using the following two helper facts.

Fact 5 ([Roc76]).

Let ğ’¦âŠ‚â„dğ’¦superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{K}\subset\mathbb{R}^{d}caligraphic_K âŠ‚ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a compact, convex set. Then for any ğ±,ğ²âˆˆâ„dğ±ğ²superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{x},\mathbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_x , bold_y âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we have

âˆ¥ğš·ğ’¦â¢(ğ±)âˆ’ğš·ğ’¦â¢(ğ²)âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥.delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğš·ğ’¦ğ±subscriptğš·ğ’¦ğ²delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ²\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{\mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{x})-\boldsymbol{\Pi}_{% \mathcal{K}}(\mathbf{y})\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert.âˆ¥ bold_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x ) - bold_Î  start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_y ) âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥ .
Lemma 11.

For any unit vectors ğ®,ğ¯âˆˆâ„dğ®ğ¯superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}bold_u , bold_v âˆˆ roman_â„ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and a,b>0ğ‘ğ‘0a,b>0italic_a , italic_b > 0, let ğ±=aâ¢ğ®ğ±ğ‘ğ®\mathbf{x}=a\mathbf{u}bold_x = italic_a bold_u and ğ²=bâ¢ğ¯ğ²ğ‘ğ¯\mathbf{y}=b\mathbf{v}bold_y = italic_b bold_v. Then, letting ğ±â€²â†(aâˆ’Î·)â¢ğ®â†superscriptğ±â€²ğ‘ğœ‚ğ®\mathbf{x}^{\prime}\leftarrow(a-\eta)\mathbf{u}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â† ( italic_a - italic_Î· ) bold_u and ğ²â€²â†(bâˆ’Î·)â¢ğ¯â†superscriptğ²â€²ğ‘ğœ‚ğ¯\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\leftarrow(b-\eta)\mathbf{v}bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â† ( italic_b - italic_Î· ) bold_v, we have âˆ¥ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ²â€²âˆ¥â‰¤maxâ¡(âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥,3â¢Î·)delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ²3ğœ‚\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\max(\left% \lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert,3\eta)âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ roman_max ( âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥ , 3 italic_Î· ).

Proof.

We claim that

âˆ¥ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ²â€²âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥â‡”a+bâ‰¥Î·,iffdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ²ğ‘ğ‘ğœ‚\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert\iff a+b\geq\eta,âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥ â‡” italic_a + italic_b â‰¥ italic_Î· , (13)

from which the proof follows from observing that if a+bâ‰¤Î·ğ‘ğ‘ğœ‚a+b\leq\etaitalic_a + italic_b â‰¤ italic_Î·, then we can trivially bound âˆ¥ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ²â€²âˆ¥â‰¤âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥+2â¢Î·â‰¤a+b+2â¢Î·â‰¤3â¢Î·delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ²2ğœ‚ğ‘ğ‘2ğœ‚3ğœ‚\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\leq\left\lVert% \mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert+2\eta\leq a+b+2\eta\leq 3\etaâˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥ + 2 italic_Î· â‰¤ italic_a + italic_b + 2 italic_Î· â‰¤ 3 italic_Î·. Indeed, (13) follows from a direct expansion:

Thus, for Î·â‰¥0ğœ‚0\eta\geq 0italic_Î· â‰¥ 0 and âŸ¨ğ®,ğ¯âŸ©â‰¥0ğ®ğ¯0\left\langle\mathbf{u},\mathbf{v}\right\rangle\geq 0âŸ¨ bold_u , bold_v âŸ© â‰¥ 0, we conclude that (13) holds. âˆ

Corollary 1.

For any phase kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] in AlgorithmÂ 4, condition on the value of ğ³0(k)superscriptsubscriptğ³0ğ‘˜\mathbf{z}_{0}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and assume that â„â„\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I contains at most mğ‘šmitalic_m copies of nğ‘›nitalic_n. Then for any 0â‰¤t<Tk0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜0\leq t<T_{k}0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the sensitivity of ğ³t(k)superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is â‰¤(2â¢m+1)â¢Î·(k)absent2ğ‘š1superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}â‰¤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

Throughout this proof only, we drop the iteration kğ‘˜kitalic_k from superscripts for notational simplicity, so we let T:=T(k)assignğ‘‡superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜T:=T^{(k)}italic_T := italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Î·:=Î·(k)assignğœ‚superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\eta:=\eta^{(k)}italic_Î· := italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, referring to the relevant iterates as {ğ³t}0â‰¤t<T:={ğ³t(k)}0â‰¤t<T(k)assignsubscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}:=\{\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}\}_{0\leq t<T^{(k)}}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also refer to the index iğ‘–iitalic_i selected on LineÂ 12 in iteration 0â‰¤t<T0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡0\leq t<T0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T by itsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡i_{t}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Fix two copies of the kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of AlgorithmÂ 4, both initialized at ğ³0subscriptğ³0\mathbf{z}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but using neighboring datasets ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D, ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT differing in the nthsuperscriptğ‘›thn^{\text{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT entry. Also, fix a realization of {it}0â‰¤t<Tsubscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{i_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, such that it=nsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘›i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n at most mğ‘šmitalic_m choices of tğ‘¡titalic_t (note that mğ‘šmitalic_m is actually a bound on how many times it=nsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘›i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n across all phases, so it certainly bounds the occurrence count in a single phase). Conditioned on this realization, AlgorithmÂ 4 is now a deterministic mapping from ğ³0subscriptğ³0\mathbf{z}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the iterates {ğ³t}0â‰¤t<Tsubscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, depending on the dataset used.

Denote the iterates given by the dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}caligraphic_D by {ğ³t}0â‰¤t<Tsubscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{\mathbf{z}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the iterates given by ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathcal{D}^{\prime}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by {ğ³tâ€²}0â‰¤t<Tsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²ğ‘¡0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡\{\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}\}_{0\leq t<T}{ bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that ğ³0=ğ³0â€²subscriptğ³0subscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²0\mathbf{z}_{0}=\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{0}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by assumption. Also, let Î¦t:=âˆ¥ğ³tâˆ’ğ³tâ€²âˆ¥assignsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ³ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²ğ‘¡\Phi_{t}:=\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}\right\rVertroman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ for all 0â‰¤t<T0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡0\leq t<T0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T. We claim that for all 0â‰¤t<T0ğ‘¡ğ‘‡0\leq t<T0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T,

Î¦tâ‰¤maxâ¡(2â¢mt+1,3)â¢Î·,Â whereÂ â¢mt:=âˆ‘0â‰¤s<tğ•€is=n,formulae-sequencesubscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡2subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡13ğœ‚assignÂ whereÂ subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡subscript0ğ‘ ğ‘¡subscriptğ•€subscriptğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘›\Phi_{t}\leq\max(2m_{t}+1,3)\eta,\text{ where }m_{t}:=\sum_{0\leq s<t}\mathbb{% I}_{i_{s}=n},roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_max ( 2 italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , 3 ) italic_Î· , where italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_s < italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ğ•€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

i.e., mtsubscriptğ‘šğ‘¡m_{t}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of times the index nğ‘›nitalic_n was sampled in the first tğ‘¡titalic_t iterations of the phase. If we can show (14) holds, then we are done because mtâ‰¤msubscriptğ‘šğ‘¡ğ‘šm_{t}\leq mitalic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_m by assumption.

We are left with proving (14), which we do by induction. The base case t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0 is clear. Suppose (14) holds at iteration tğ‘¡titalic_t. In iteration t+1ğ‘¡1t+1italic_t + 1, if mt+1=mt+1subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘šğ‘¡1m_{t+1}=m_{t}+1italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 (i.e., it=nsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘›i_{t}=nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_n was sampled), then (14) holds by the triangle inequality and the induction hypothesis, because all gradient steps Î·â¢ğ tğœ‚subscriptğ ğ‘¡\eta\mathbf{g}_{t}italic_Î· bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT have âˆ¥Î·â¢ğ tâˆ¥â‰¤Î·delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğœ‚subscriptğ ğ‘¡ğœ‚\left\lVert\eta\mathbf{g}_{t}\right\rVert\leq\etaâˆ¥ italic_Î· bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ italic_Î·, and projection to ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K}caligraphic_K can only decrease distances (FactÂ 5). Otherwise, let it=iâ‰ nsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘›i_{t}=i\neq nitalic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_i â‰  italic_n be the sampled index, using the common point ğ±iâˆˆğ’Ÿâˆ©ğ’Ÿâ€²subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²\mathbf{x}_{i}\in\mathcal{D}\cap\mathcal{D}^{\prime}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_D âˆ© caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now, (14) follows from applying LemmaÂ 11 with

ğ±â†ğ³tâˆ’ğ±i,ğ²â†ğ³tâ€²âˆ’ğ±i,ğ®â†ğ³tâˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥ğ³tâˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥,ğ¯â†ğ³tâ€²âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥ğ³tâ€²âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥.formulae-sequenceâ†ğ±subscriptğ³ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–formulae-sequenceâ†ğ²subscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–formulae-sequenceâ†ğ®subscriptğ³ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ³ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–â†ğ¯subscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptsuperscriptğ³â€²ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{x}\leftarrow\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i},\;\mathbf{y}\leftarrow% \mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i},\;\mathbf{u}\leftarrow\frac{\mathbf{z}_% {t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert},\;% \mathbf{v}\leftarrow\frac{\mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert% \mathbf{z}^{\prime}_{t}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert}.bold_x â† bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_y â† bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_u â† divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG , bold_v â† divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG .

In particular, we have that âˆ¥ğ±âˆ’ğ²âˆ¥=Î¦tdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ±ğ²subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡\left\lVert\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{y}\right\rVert=\Phi_{t}âˆ¥ bold_x - bold_y âˆ¥ = roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and âˆ¥ğ±â€²âˆ’ğ²â€²âˆ¥â‰¥Î¦t+1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğ±â€²superscriptğ²â€²subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡1\left\lVert\mathbf{x}^{\prime}-\mathbf{y}^{\prime}\right\rVert\geq\Phi_{t+1}âˆ¥ bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¥ roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (due to FactÂ 5), following notation from LemmaÂ 11. We thus have Î¦t+1â‰¤maxâ¡(Î¦t,3â¢Î·)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ¦ğ‘¡3ğœ‚\Phi_{t+1}\leq\max(\Phi_{t},3\eta)roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ roman_max ( roman_Î¦ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 3 italic_Î· ), which clearly also preserves (14) inductively. âˆ

We can now conclude our privacy proof by applying composition to CorollaryÂ 1.

Lemma 12.

Let Ïµâˆˆ[0,1]italic-Ïµ01\epsilon\in[0,1]italic_Ïµ âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]. If 1Ïâ‰¥4â¢logâ¡(2Î´)Ïµ2+2Ïµ1ğœŒ42ğ›¿superscriptitalic-Ïµ22italic-Ïµ\frac{1}{\rho}\geq\frac{4\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{2}{\epsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG â‰¥ divide start_ARG 4 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG, AlgorithmÂ 4 is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP.

Proof.

We claim that AlgorithmÂ 4 satisfies ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï-CDP, conditioned on â„â„\mathcal{I}caligraphic_I containing at most mğ‘šmitalic_m choices of tğ‘¡titalic_t (we denote this conditional variant by ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A). By applying the second part of FactÂ 4 with Î±â†2â¢logâ¡(2Î´)Ïµ+1â†ğ›¼22ğ›¿italic-Ïµ1\alpha\leftarrow\frac{2\log(\frac{2}{\delta})}{\epsilon}+1italic_Î± â† divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïµ end_ARG + 1, this implies that ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is (Ïµ,Î´2)italic-Ïµğ›¿2(\epsilon,\frac{\delta}{2})( italic_Ïµ , divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )-DP. Because ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A has total variation distance at most Î´8ğ›¿8\frac{\delta}{8}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG to AlgorithmÂ 4 due to LemmaÂ 10, we conclude using LemmaÂ 1 that AlgorithmÂ 4 is (Ïµ,Î´)italic-Ïµğ›¿(\epsilon,\delta)( italic_Ïµ , italic_Î´ )-DP.

We are left to show ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A satisfies ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï-CDP. In fact, we will show that for all kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ], the output of the kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, i.e., ğ±^(k)superscript^ğ±ğ‘˜\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, satisfies (169)âˆ’kâ‹…Ï2â‹…superscript169ğ‘˜ğœŒ2(\frac{16}{9})^{-k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}( divide start_ARG 16 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG-CDP (treating the starting iterate ğ³0(k)=ğ±^(kâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ³0ğ‘˜superscript^ğ±ğ‘˜1\mathbf{z}_{0}^{(k)}=\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)}bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as fixed). Using composition of RDP (the first part of FactÂ 4), this implies ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A is ÏğœŒ\rhoitalic_Ï-CDP as desired.

Finally, we bound the CDP of phase kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K]italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ]. Under ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A, we showed in CorollaryÂ 1 that all iterates of the kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase have sensitivity â‰¤(2â¢m+1)â¢Î·(k)absent2ğ‘š1superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}â‰¤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus the average iterate ğ±Â¯(k)superscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT also has sensitivity â‰¤(2â¢m+1)â¢Î·(k)absent2ğ‘š1superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜\leq(2m+1)\eta^{(k)}â‰¤ ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by the triangle inequality. We can now bound the CDP of the kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase using the third part of FactÂ 4:

((2â¢m+1)â¢Î·(k))22â¢(Ïƒ(k))2=((2â¢m+1)â¢Î·)2((2â¢m+1)â¢Î·)2â‹…16âˆ’kâ‹…9kâ‹…Ï2â‰¤(169)âˆ’kâ‹…Ï2.superscript2ğ‘š1superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜22superscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘˜2â‹…superscript2ğ‘š1ğœ‚2superscript2ğ‘š1ğœ‚2superscript16ğ‘˜superscript9ğ‘˜ğœŒ2â‹…superscript169ğ‘˜ğœŒ2\frac{((2m+1)\eta^{(k)})^{2}}{2(\sigma^{(k)})^{2}}=\frac{((2m+1)\eta)^{2}}{((2% m+1)\eta)^{2}}\cdot 16^{-k}\cdot 9^{k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}\leq\left(\frac{16}{9% }\right)^{-k}\cdot\frac{\rho}{2}.divide start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( ( 2 italic_m + 1 ) italic_Î· ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‹… 16 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… 9 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG â‰¤ ( divide start_ARG 16 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… divide start_ARG italic_Ï end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

âˆ

4.2 Utility of AlgorithmÂ 4

We now analyze the error guarantees for AlgorithmÂ 4 on optimizing the geometric median objective fğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿf_{\mathcal{D}}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (3). We begin by providing a high-probability bound on the utility guarantees of each single phase.

Lemma 13.

Following notation of AlgorithmÂ 4, we have with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´2absent1ğ›¿2\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG that

fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(1)âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)â‰¤r^22â¢Î·(1)â¢T(1)+Î·(1)2+4â¢r^â¢2â¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)T(1),f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(1})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})\leq% \frac{\hat{r}^{2}}{2\eta^{(1)}T^{(1)}}+\frac{\eta^{(1)}}{2}+4\hat{r}\sqrt{% \frac{2\log(\frac{4K}{\delta})}{T^{(1)}}},italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ,

where ğ±â‹†:=argminğ±âˆˆğ”¹dâ¢(ğ±Â¯,r^)â¢fâ¢(ğ±)assignsubscriptğ±â‹†subscriptargminğ±superscriptğ”¹ğ‘‘Â¯ğ±^ğ‘Ÿğ‘“ğ±\mathbf{x}_{\star}:=\textup{argmin}_{\mathbf{x}\in\mathbb{B}^{d}(\bar{\mathbf{% x}},\hat{r})}f(\mathbf{x})bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := argmin start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x âˆˆ roman_ğ”¹ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG , over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( bold_x ), and

fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(k))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(kâˆ’1))â‰¤2â¢(Ïƒ(k))2â¢dâ¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)Î·(k)â¢T(k)+Î·(k)2+8â¢Ïƒ(k)â¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)â¢2â¢dT(k)â¢Â for allÂ â¢2â‰¤kâ‰¤K.subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜12superscriptsuperscriptğœğ‘˜2ğ‘‘4ğ¾ğ›¿superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜28superscriptğœğ‘˜4ğ¾ğ›¿2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜Â for allÂ 2ğ‘˜ğ¾f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1% )})\leq\frac{2(\sigma^{(k)})^{2}d\log(\frac{4K}{\delta})}{\eta^{(k)}T^{(k)}}+% \frac{\eta^{(k)}}{2}+8\sigma^{(k)}\log\left(\frac{4K}{\delta}\right)\sqrt{% \frac{2d}{T^{(k)}}}\text{ for all }2\leq k\leq K.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 8 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_d end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG for all 2 â‰¤ italic_k â‰¤ italic_K .
Proof.

First, with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´4absent1ğ›¿4\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{4}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG, we have

âˆ¥ğƒ(k)âˆ¥â‰¤2â¢Ïƒ(k)â¢dâ¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)â¢Â for allÂ â¢kâˆˆ[K],delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğƒğ‘˜2superscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘‘4ğ¾ğ›¿Â for allÂ ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(k)}\right\rVert\leq 2\sigma^{(k)}\sqrt{d\log% \left(\frac{4K}{\delta}\right)}\text{ for all }k\in[K],âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG for all italic_k âˆˆ [ italic_K ] ,

by standard Gaussian concentration. Thus, ğ±Â¯(kâˆ’1)âˆˆğ’¦(k)superscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜1superscriptğ’¦ğ‘˜\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)}\in\mathcal{K}^{(k)}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all 2â‰¤kâ‰¤K2ğ‘˜ğ¾2\leq k\leq K2 â‰¤ italic_k â‰¤ italic_K, and ğ±â‹†âˆˆğ’¦(1)subscriptğ±â‹†superscriptğ’¦1\mathbf{x}_{\star}\in\mathcal{K}^{(1)}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, except with probability Î´4ğ›¿4\frac{\delta}{4}divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG. Next, consider the kthsuperscriptğ‘˜thk^{\text{th}}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT phase of AlgorithmÂ 4, and for some 0â‰¤t<Tk0ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜0\leq t<T_{k}0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, let us denote

ğ ~t(k):=ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥assignsuperscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ±ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ±ğ‘–\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)}:=\frac{\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left% \lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert}over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG

where iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] is the random index sampled on LineÂ 12 in the tthsuperscriptğ‘¡tht^{\text{th}}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT iteration of phase kğ‘˜kitalic_k. We also denote

ğ t(k):=1nâ¢âˆ‘iâˆˆ[n]ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ±iâˆ¥.assignsuperscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ±ğ‘–delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ±ğ‘–\mathbf{g}_{t}^{(k)}:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i\in[n]}\frac{\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-% \mathbf{x}_{i}}{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{x}_{i}\right\rVert}.bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG .

We observe that ğ”¼â¢[ğ ~t(k)]=ğ t(k)ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)}]=\mathbf{g}_{t}^{(k)}roman_ğ”¼ [ over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any realization of the randomness in all previous iterations. âŸ¨Î·(k)â¢ğ ~t(k),ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©â‰¤âˆ¥ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ®âˆ¥22âˆ’âˆ¥ğ³t+1(k)âˆ’ğ®âˆ¥22+(Î·(k))22.superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ®superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ®22superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡1ğ‘˜ğ®22superscriptsuperscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜22\left\langle\eta^{(k)}\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-% \mathbf{u}\right\rangle\leq\frac{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{u}% \right\rVert^{2}}{2}-\frac{\left\lVert\mathbf{z}_{t+1}^{(k)}-\mathbf{u}\right% \rVert^{2}}{2}+\frac{(\eta^{(k)})^{2}}{2}.âŸ¨ italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âŸ© â‰¤ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG ( italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG . (15)

Here we implicitly used that âˆ¥ğ ~t(k)âˆ¥â‰¤1delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜1\lVert\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)}\rVert\leq 1âˆ¥ over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 1 for all choices of the sampled index iâˆˆ[n]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘›i\in[n]italic_i âˆˆ [ italic_n ]. 1T(k)â¢âˆ‘0â‰¤t<T(k)âŸ¨ğ ~t(k),ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©â‰¤âˆ¥ğ³0(k)âˆ’ğ®âˆ¥22â¢Î·(k)â¢T(k)+Î·(k)2.1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ®superscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptsubscriptğ³0ğ‘˜ğ®22superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜superscriptğœ‚ğ‘˜2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T^{(k)}}\sum_{0\leq t<T^{(k)}}\left\langle\tilde{\mathbf% {g}}_{t}^{(k)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{u}\right\rangle\leq\frac{\left% \lVert\mathbf{z}_{0}^{(k)}-\mathbf{u}\right\rVert^{2}}{2\eta^{(k)}T^{(k)}}+% \frac{\eta^{(k)}}{2}.divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âŸ© â‰¤ divide start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_Î· start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

Next, we claim that with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´4absent1ğ›¿4\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{4}â‰¥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG,

1T(1)â¢âˆ‘0â‰¤t<T(1)âŸ¨ğ t(1)âˆ’ğ ~t(1),ğ³t(1)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©1superscriptğ‘‡1subscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡1ğ®\displaystyle\frac{1}{T^{(1)}}\sum_{0\leq t<T^{(1)}}\left\langle\mathbf{g}_{t}% ^{(1)}-\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(1)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(1)}-\mathbf{u}\right\rangledivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âŸ© â‰¤4â¢r^â¢2â¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)T(1),absent4^ğ‘Ÿ24ğ¾ğ›¿superscriptğ‘‡1\displaystyle\leq 4\hat{r}\sqrt{\frac{2\log\left(\frac{4K}{\delta}\right)}{T^{% (1)}}},â‰¤ 4 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG ,

In each case, this is because âŸ¨ğ t(k)âˆ’ğ ~t(k),ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscript~ğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ®\langle\mathbf{g}_{t}^{(k)}-\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{(k)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-% \mathbf{u}\rangleâŸ¨ bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over~ start_ARG bold_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âŸ© is a mean-zero random variable, that is bounded (with probability 1111) by twice the diameter of ğ’¦(k)superscriptğ’¦ğ‘˜\mathcal{K}^{(k)}caligraphic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus we can bound the sub-Gaussian parameter of their sum, and applying the Azuma-Hoeffding inequality then gives the result. Now, finally by convexity,

1T(1)â¢âˆ‘0â‰¤t<T(1)âŸ¨ğ t(1),ğ³t(1)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©1superscriptğ‘‡1subscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡1superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡1superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡1ğ®\displaystyle\frac{1}{T^{(1)}}\sum_{0\leq t<T^{(1)}}\left\langle\mathbf{g}_{t}% ^{(1)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(1)}-\mathbf{u}\right\rangledivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_u âŸ© â‰¥1T(1)â¢âˆ‘0â‰¤t<T(1)fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ³t(1))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ®)â‰¥fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(1))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ®),absent1superscriptğ‘‡1subscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡1subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğ³1ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ®subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±1subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿğ®\displaystyle\geq\frac{1}{T^{(1)}}\sum_{0\leq t<T^{(1)}}f_{\mathcal{D}}(% \mathbf{z}^{(1)}_{t})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{u})\geq f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{% \mathbf{x}}^{(1)})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{u}),â‰¥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) â‰¥ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_u ) ,
1T(k)â¢âˆ‘0â‰¤t<T(k)âŸ¨ğ t(k),ğ³t(k)âˆ’ğ®âŸ©1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜subscript0ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ³ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğ®\displaystyle\frac{1}{T^{(k)}}\sum_{0\leq t<T^{(k)}}\left\langle\mathbf{g}_{t}% ^{(k)},\mathbf{z}_{t}^{(k)}-\mathbf{u}\right\rangledivide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 â‰¤ italic_t < italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ¨ bold_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - Combining the above three displays, and plugging in ğ®â†ğ±â‹†â†ğ®subscriptğ±â‹†\mathbf{u}\leftarrow\mathbf{x}_{\star}bold_u â† bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ®â†ğ±Â¯(kâˆ’1)â†ğ®superscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜1\mathbf{u}\leftarrow\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)}bold_u â† overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, now gives the conclusion. âˆ

By summing the conclusion of LemmaÂ 13 across all phases, we obtain an overall error bound.

Lemma 14.

Following notation of AlgorithmÂ 4 and LemmaÂ 13, we have with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ that

fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±^(K))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)â‰¤r^216â¢Î·â¢T+19â¢Î·+8â¢r^â¢logâ¡(4â¢KÎ´)T+1314â¢Tâ¢Î·â¢dâ¢log4â¡(8â¢KÎ´)Ïâ¢n2.subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsuperscript^ğ±ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†superscript^ğ‘Ÿ216ğœ‚ğ‘‡19ğœ‚8^ğ‘Ÿ4ğ¾ğ›¿ğ‘‡1314ğ‘‡ğœ‚ğ‘‘superscript48ğ¾ğ›¿ğœŒsuperscriptğ‘›2f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}^{(K)})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}_{\star})% \leq\frac{\hat{r}^{2}}{16\eta T}+19\eta+8\hat{r}\sqrt{\frac{\log(\frac{4K}{% \delta})}{T}}+\frac{1314T\eta d\log^{4}(\frac{8K}{\delta})}{\rho n^{2}}.italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¤ divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 16 italic_Î· italic_T end_ARG + 19 italic_Î· + 8 over^ start_ARG italic_r end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_T end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1314 italic_T italic_Î· italic_d roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 8 italic_K end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ï italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .
Proof.

Throughout this proof, condition on the conclusion of LemmaÂ 13 holding, as well as

âˆ¥ğƒ(K)âˆ¥â‰¤2â¢Ïƒ(K)â¢dâ¢logâ¡(2Î´),delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥superscriptğƒğ¾2superscriptğœğ¾ğ‘‘2ğ›¿\left\lVert\boldsymbol{\xi}^{(K)}\right\rVert\leq 2\sigma^{(K)}\sqrt{d\log% \left(\frac{2}{\delta}\right)},âˆ¥ bold_italic_Î¾ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‰¤ 2 italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_K ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_d roman_log ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Î´ end_ARG ) end_ARG ,

both of which hold with probability â‰¥1âˆ’Î´absent1ğ›¿\geq 1-\deltaâ‰¥ 1 - italic_Î´ by a union bound. Next, by LemmaÂ 13,

fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±^K)âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscript^ğ±ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†\displaystyle f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{K})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{x}% _{\star})italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(1))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±â‹†)+âˆ‘k=2Kfğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(k))âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯(kâˆ’1))+fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±^K)âˆ’fğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ±Â¯K)absentsubscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±1subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ±â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜2ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsuperscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘“ğ’Ÿsubscript^ğ±ğ¾subscriptğ‘“ğ’ŸsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ¾\displaystyle=f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(1)})-f_{\mathcal{D}}(\mathbf{% x}_{\star})+\sum_{k=2}^{K}f_{\mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k)})-f_{\mathcal{% D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}^{(k-1)})+f_{\mathcal{D}}(\hat{\mathbf{x}}_{K})-f_{% \mathcal{D}}(\bar{\mathbf{x}}_{K})= italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_k - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
